**Tinseltown's Most Terrific Tea Party! Admission is Free for All!**

Carl hammered the sign down on the cracking concrete in front of the rusted, disused warehouse and stared at his partner Ralph. "Bro, you sure this is going to lure in that pesky detective who keeps foiling Boss Bernando's plans?"

"Carl, you dumbass!" Ralph slapped him on the back of his head with a goat plush toy. "Didn't boss make it clear? We're kidnapping the loved one of Detective Watson as bait. She wouldn't fall for such an elementary trick. But her dorky boyfriend will."

"Right, right. So, what do we know about Katrina Watson's boyfriend?"

"He's obsessed with tea and cakes, and goats," Ralph read his briefing notes. "We're serving chamomile tea, strawberry cheesecakes and he can go pet some goats at the back of this warehouse."

"What does he look like?"

"Some goth LARPer who dresses like a necromancer in black robes. Pale, white-haired guy."

"That one?" Carl pointed to the strange man sauntering towards them on...tentacles? Those have got to be some fake animatronic, right?

Ralph nodded, "That one."

"Greetings humans!" Their target waved at them with a cheery grin. "Ah, the Tinseltown's Tea Party! Boy, am I glad to have free flow of tea and cakes! Where do I register?"

"The guestbook's right here," Ralph presented to him the book he purchased from Poppa's Art and Craft shop just twenty minutes ago. "Sign here."

*Lord Elvari was here! :D*

*Who doesn't love tea parties! :P*

"There! I've signed it. Let's get down to the party, shall we?" He rubbed his hands, and those oddly realistic tentacles together. "You can't have free lunches all the time, but I'm sure am glad free tea parties exist!"

Carl kept his head down and his mouth shut while Ralph led their gullible and eager target inside. The cheap plastic utensils, scrappy tablecloth they bought off a second-hand goods store, and the paltry Christmas decorations they salvaged from an impoverished orphanage, would that dork really buy it? About the only thing that costed more than pocket change was the exquisite porcelain teapot and silver serving platter for the cake. That's the most important things, Ralph said. The things that their target would focus on. And the tea, of course.

"You sure do have many armed guards for a simple tea party," Elvari scanned the sparsely decorated warehouse and pointed towards the gang members standing by armed and ready.

"Yea, we want to ensure our VIP party guest is secure in our premises," Ralph said. "That'll be you, our honored guest."

"Why, thank you. How very considerate of you."

"Only the best for our guest," Ralph forced a smile on his face and gestured his kidnapping target towards the sole table and chair in the area. "Would you like to take a seat and enjoy what we have to offer?"

The weirdo in black robes plopped himself down on the chair and poured himself some tea. No sooner than he aimed his fork towards the cheesecake, the warehouse door slammed open.

"Freeze!" Detective Katrina Watson shouted as she aimed her gun towards Ralph. "You're under arrest for kidnapping...Elvari?"

"Kidnapping?" He sounded displeased. "I was told this was a tea party!"

"It's a kidnapping," Carl pressed the muzzle of his gun against Elvari's head. "Detective, take a step closer and I'll blow his brains out."

"Which brain?" Elvari asked in the puzzled tone. "I have nine of these squiggly organs you call brains."

"Oh god Elvari, this is not the time for jokes!" Kat bemoaned. "Not when you're the target of a kidnapping attempt."

"But I do actually have nine brains in total..." he pouted and tented his tentacles. "I know...they've been accused of sharing one same braincell at times, but they're still nine separate brains."

"Boys, I'd advise you put your guns down," Kat spoke to the armed gangsters surrounding them. "You have picked literally the worst target to kidnap to impede my investigations. Not because he's a big dork who thinks there could be a real tea party in an abandoned warehouse. Because he's an actual eldritch deity who could shatter your minds and have you pissing in your diapers in a psychiatric ward for life."

The men backed away with their guns down. A few ran out the door and never looked back. Ralph kept his gun on Kat, while Carl —

*Bang!*

Blood trickled down from the side of Elvari's head. He sat still, eyes wide open, before blinking.

"That wasn't very nice of you," he frowned while his tentacles hissed angrily. "I was suspicious of the abandoned warehouse setup, but the tea was just too good, so I thought I should be a gracious guest and play along. But playtime's over."

A tentacle coiled around Carl's hand to twist it until audible cracking sounds echoed across the room, alongside the gangster's screams. His gun fell to the floor, as did his knees crashed down onto the concrete. Ralph let out gurgling noises when a tentacle throttled his throat. Both unable to protest while tentacles slapped them repeatedly in their faces. Elvari continued to sip his tea and stuffed his face with cake like it was a pleasant afternoon at his favourite cafe and totally not punishing two gangsters for a failed kidnapping attempt at an old warehouse.

"Elvari? You can stop now," Kat squeezed his shoulder. "I've notified Officer Jenkins to come by and make an arrest, so please leave those two to be recognizable by other scam victims at a line-up, okay?
story_a:
I should've known something was off the moment I stepped into the neighborhood. The air was thick with the scent of blooming roses and freshly cut grass, an odd juxtaposition to the task at hand. My target was a high-profile scientist who had crossed the wrong people, and my mission was to kidnap his loved one as leverage. Simple, right? Except, nothing about this felt simple.

I approached the house, a quaint two-story with ivy creeping up the brick exterior. The intel said she’d be alone—his wife, a schoolteacher with a penchant for gardening. Easy pickings. I jimmied the lock on the back door, the click of the mechanism echoing in the silent kitchen. My heart pounded in my chest, but I dismissed it as the usual pre-job jitters.

The kitchen was immaculate, almost sterile in its cleanliness. A bowl of apples sat on the counter, and I noticed the faint aroma of freshly baked bread lingering in the air. It was the kind of place that screamed "normalcy," but there was something else, an underlying tension that set my instincts on edge.

I crept through the house, careful to avoid the creaky floorboards. The living room was tastefully decorated, with family photos lining the walls. There she was, sitting on a plush armchair, reading a book. Her long, auburn hair cascaded over her shoulders, and she looked up, locking eyes with me.

"Can I help you?" she asked, her voice calm and measured. No hint of fear, no surprise. Just... calm.

"Mrs. Thompson," I said, trying to sound authoritative. "I need you to come with me."

She closed her book and placed it on the side table, standing up with an elegance that seemed almost rehearsed. "Is that so?" she replied, a small smile playing on her lips. "And what if I say no?"

I pulled out my gun, leveling it at her. "Then things get messy."

Her smile widened, and for the first time, I felt a chill run down my spine. "You really should have done your homework," she said, and before I could react, she moved.

One moment she was standing there, and the next, she was a blur of motion. My gun was knocked from my hand, and I found myself on the floor, gasping for breath. Her knee was pressed against my chest, and her eyes bore into mine with an intensity that made my blood run cold.

"Who sent you?" she demanded, her voice now a dangerous whisper.

I struggled to breathe, my mind racing. This wasn't supposed to happen. She was supposed to be easy, a means to an end. But now, with her hand gripping my throat, I realized I was the one in over my head.

"Talk!" she snapped, tightening her grip.

"V-Veritas," I choked out, the word barely escaping my lips. "They want your husband."

Her eyes narrowed, and she released her hold, allowing me to gasp for air. "Of course they do," she muttered, almost to herself. "Fools."

She stood up, giving me a chance to scramble to my feet. I rubbed my throat, my mind racing with thoughts of escape, but something about her presence kept me rooted to the spot.

"What's your name?" she asked, her tone softer now, almost gentle.

"Marcus," I replied, still wary.

"Well, Marcus," she said, picking up the book she had been reading. "It seems you've found yourself in quite the predicament. You see, Veritas didn't just send you to kidnap a schoolteacher. They sent you to kidnap me—an operative they thought was long retired."

Her words hung in the air, and my mind struggled to process the implications. She was one of them? A former operative? No wonder she had taken me down so easily.

"They didn't tell you, did they?" she continued, shaking her head. "Typical. They always underestimate the people they cast aside."

I took a step back, my instincts screaming at me to run, but she held up a hand. "Wait. I'm not going to hurt you."

"Why should I believe you?" I asked, my voice trembling.

"Because you and I, we're pawns in a game much larger than ourselves," she said, her eyes softening. "And if there's one thing I've learned, it's that pawns can change the course of the game."

She walked over to the window, peering out into the night. "You have a choice, Marcus. You can leave now, go back to Veritas, and tell them you failed. Or," she turned to face me, "you can help me take them down."

I hesitated, the weight of her words settling over me. She was offering me a chance to flip the script, to turn the tables on those who had sent me here. It was dangerous, reckless even, but something in her eyes told me she was serious.

"What do you need me to do?" I asked, the decision made.

Her smile returned, this time warm and genuine. "First, we're going to pay my husband a visit. He's been working on something that might just give us the upper hand."

As we left the house together, I couldn't help but feel a sense of anticipation. The game was changing, and for the first time, I wasn't just a pawn. I was a player.
story_b:
Derek had done a lot of jobs in his time, but this one took the cake. Kidnapping a loved one to get to the target? It was dirty work, but it paid well. Desperation breeds creativity, or so he told himself. The address led him to an old mansion, the kind that seemed to breathe its own history. Every corner of the place whispered secrets.

“Alright, let's get this over with,” Derek muttered, adjusting the mask on his face. “This can't be any harder than that time in Madrid.”

He slipped in through an unlocked window—an open invitation, really. The mansion was eerily quiet, save for the occasional creak of wood. As he moved through the dimly lit corridors, he couldn't shake the feeling of being watched.

Derek found her in a room at the far end of the hallway. She was seated in a large, ornate chair, seemingly engrossed in a book. She looked up, eyes like deep pools of midnight. Young, no older than twenty, with a frail appearance that belied the danger he was warned about.

“She can't be that dangerous,” Derek thought, a smirk tugging at his lips. “She looks like she couldn't hurt a fly.”

“Hello there,” he said, attempting to sound intimidating. “You're coming with me.”

She closed her book gently, placing it on a small table beside her. “Do you know who I am?” Her voice was soft, almost musical, but it carried an undertone that made Derek's skin crawl.

“Yeah, you're coming with me to make your boyfriend talk,” Derek said, pulling out a pair of handcuffs. “Now, let's make this easy.”

Her laugh was light, almost innocent. “Boyfriend? Is that what you think?” She stood up, and Derek was taken aback by how gracefully she moved. “I think you might be mistaken about a few things.”

“Just—just turn around,” Derek stammered, waving the handcuffs. “No funny business.”

The next moment happened in a blur. One second she was standing there, the next, Derek was flying across the room, crashing into an antique cabinet. The air crackled with an energy that made his hair stand on end.

“What the hell?” Derek groaned, struggling to his feet. “What are you?”

She walked over to him, her steps soundless on the wooden floor. “You poor thing. You have no idea what you’ve walked into, do you?” She extended a hand, and Derek felt an invisible force lifting him off the ground.

“Let me go!” Derek shouted, writhing in mid-air.

“You should have done your homework,” she said, her eyes glowing with an eerie light. Shadows around the room seemed to dance and twist, moving to some unseen rhythm. “I’m not some damsel in distress. I’m the one they tell stories about to keep you up at night.”

Derek’s mind raced. He had to think of something, anything. “Look, I just—”

“Save it,” she interrupted, her tone cold. “You were sent here to kidnap me, right? To use me as bait?”

“Y-yeah,” Derek admitted, his bravado crumbling. “I didn’t know you were… this.”

She tilted her head, a curious look in her eyes. “And now that you know, what will you do?”

Derek swallowed hard. “I… I don’t know. I just wanted the money.”

She seemed to consider this for a moment. “Money, is it? And what will you do with that money?”

“Get out,” Derek said quickly. “Start over. Leave this life behind.”

“Interesting.” She released her hold, and Derek dropped to the floor with a thud. “You’re not the first to come after me, you know. But you might be the first with a shred of honesty.”

Derek rubbed his sore limbs, trying to process what was happening. “So… what now?”

She smiled, a disconcerting blend of warmth and menace. “Now, we talk. You see, my beloved isn’t what you think. He’s part of something much larger, something darker. And you, my dear kidnapper, might just be the key to turning the tide.”

“What are you talking about?” Derek asked, genuinely confused.

“There’s a war coming,” she said, her eyes distant, as if seeing something far away. “A war between those who want to control, and those who want to be free. My beloved is on the wrong side, and so was I, once. But you, you could help us.”

“Help you?” Derek echoed, incredulous. “You just tossed me across the room like a rag doll.”

She laughed again, a sound that sent chills down his spine. “Yes, I did. And I could do much worse. But I see potential in you. You’re desperate enough to change, to do what’s necessary.”

Derek took a deep breath. “Alright, say I believe you. What’s the plan?”

She extended her hand again, this time in a gesture of alliance. “We start by taking down the ones who sent you. They’re the real danger here.”

Derek hesitated, then took her hand. “Okay. But if this goes south, I’m blaming you.”

“Fair enough,” she said, a mischievous glint in her eye. “Let’s get to work.”

As they left the mansion together, Derek couldn’t help but wonder what he had gotten himself into. One thing was certain: his life was never going to be the same.

The mission was supposed to be straightforward. Kidnap the loved one of the infamous sorcerer Alaric, use them as bait to lure him out, and then deliver him to the council. Easy enough, right? I'd handled tougher jobs. As I crept through the dimly lit corridors of the mansion, my confidence wavered only slightly. The target was supposed to be harmless—a scholar, not a warrior. But as I approached their study, the flickering candlelight cast strange shadows that made my skin prickle with unease.

I paused at the doorway, peering inside. The room was cluttered with scrolls and books, the air thick with the smell of parchment and ink. In the center sat a figure, their back to me, seemingly engrossed in a tome. My heart beat steadily as I stepped forward, a soft whisper of movement. Then, the figure turned, and I found myself staring into eyes that gleamed with a predatory awareness that sent a chill down my spine.

"You're not the first to try this," they said, their voice calm yet laced with amusement. "And I doubt you'll be the last."

I barely had time to react before the room seemed to come alive. Books flew from the shelves, their pages cutting through the air like blades. I ducked, narrowly avoiding a tome that whizzed past my ear. My instincts screamed at me to retreat, but my pride urged me forward. I was a professional, after all.

The scholar—no, the warrior—moved with a grace that belied their scholarly appearance. They flicked their wrist, and shadows pooled at their feet, rising up to obscure their form. I darted sideways, hoping to flank them, but the shadows followed, twisting and turning to keep me at bay.

"You thought this would be easy, didn't you?" Their voice echoed around the room, disembodied, as if the very walls were speaking. "Most people do."

I didn't answer. Instead, I grabbed a nearby chair, using it as a makeshift shield against the relentless assault of flying books. The absurdity of the situation was not lost on me, and I couldn't help but chuckle. Outmatched by a librarian—what a way to go.

With a sudden burst of inspiration, I swung the chair, scattering the books momentarily. I seized the opportunity to dive behind a desk, catching my breath. I needed a new plan. Clearly, I was dealing with someone far more formidable than anticipated.

The shadows danced around the room, and I knew I had to act fast. I rummaged through my pouch, fingers closing around a small vial of oil. With a quick flick of my wrist, I splashed it across the floor, igniting it with a spark from a flint.

The fire blazed to life, the light banishing the shadows to the corners of the room. For the first time, I saw the scholar fully—their features sharp, eyes glinting with intelligence and something else, something dangerous.

They paused, assessing me with a curious tilt of their head. "Clever," they admitted, the hint of a smile on their lips. "But not clever enough."

With a flick of their hand, the flames sputtered out, leaving only smoke and the smell of charred wood. I cursed under my breath. This was not going to end well.

In that moment of quiet, I realized I had underestimated them entirely. They weren't just defending themselves; they were toying with me. I had to rethink my strategy, and fast.

A sudden idea struck me. Maybe brute force wasn't the answer. Maybe... maybe I could talk my way out of this. It was a long shot, but better than the alternative.

"Look," I said, raising my hands in a gesture of peace. "This isn't personal. It's just business."

They regarded me with a mixture of skepticism and curiosity, the shadows receding slightly. "Business? Kidnapping is a poor business indeed."

I shrugged, trying to appear nonchalant. "True. But what if we could make it... mutually beneficial?"

The scholar laughed, a sound both musical and dangerous. "And what exactly do you propose?"

"An alliance," I suggested, the words tumbling out before I could second-guess them. "You help me take down Alaric, and in return, I make sure the council leaves you alone."

Their eyes narrowed, considering my offer. For a moment, the only sound was the crackle of the dying fire. Then, slowly, they nodded.

"Very well," they said, extending a hand. "But betray me, and you'll find this encounter was the least of your worries."

I took their hand, sealing our unexpected alliance. As we left the study, a new plan forming in my mind, I couldn't help but feel a grudging respect for my would-be target. They had been more than a match for me, and now, perhaps, they would be the ally I never knew I needed.

In the end, I realized, it wasn't about the mission. It was about the unexpected paths we take and the unlikely alliances we forge along the way.

On the surface, Lisa appeared to be just another young woman enjoying her morning coffee at the quaint little café by the river. The sun's gentle rays danced on the water, creating a serene and picturesque scene that belied the chaos about to unfold. I watched her from a distance, my orders clear: kidnap her and use her as bait to draw out her lover, the infamous thief known only as The Specter.

"Piece of cake," I muttered to myself, adjusting the collar of my jacket and taking a deep breath. I had no idea how wrong I was.

I approached her table, feigning a casual interest in the menu. "Excuse me, miss. Do you mind if I join you? The place is quite packed today."

She looked up, her eyes a striking shade of green that seemed to pierce right through me. "Sure, have a seat," she said with a warm smile. Her voice was calm, almost melodic.

As I sat down, I couldn't help but notice the subtle way she scanned her surroundings, as if cataloging every exit and potential threat. "So, what brings you here?" I asked, trying to keep my tone light and conversational.

"Oh, just enjoying a quiet morning," she replied, taking a sip of her coffee. "And you?"

"Same," I said, forcing a smile. "Actually, I was hoping to get to know you better."

Her smile didn't waver, but there was a glint of amusement in her eyes. "Is that so? Well, I'm flattered."

Before I could react, she moved. Her hand shot out, grabbing my wrist with a grip like iron. She twisted, and I found myself face down on the table, my arm pinned painfully behind my back. The café patrons continued their conversations, oblivious to the sudden violence.

"You really should do your homework before attempting something like this," she whispered in my ear, her breath warm against my skin. "Did you honestly think you could kidnap me?"

I struggled, trying to break free, but her grip was unyielding. "Who are you?" I gasped, the pain in my arm intensifying.

"Let's just say I'm not as helpless as I look," she replied, releasing me abruptly. I stumbled back, rubbing my wrist and glaring at her.

"Why didn't you just kill me?" I spat, my pride wounded more than my body.

She shrugged, leaning back in her chair. "Because I want to know who sent you and why."

From the corner of my eye, I saw a shadow move—The Specter, no doubt, lurking nearby and watching us. He must have known she was dangerous, but he didn't intervene. Why?

"Fine," I said, deciding to play along. "I was sent to kidnap you to get to The Specter. Happy now?"

Her laughter was soft but chilling. "Oh, you poor fool. Did you really think you could use me against him? We've been aware of your little plan from the start."

My heart sank. "What do you mean?"

She leaned forward, her eyes locking onto mine. "I knew you were coming. I let you get close because I wanted to see if you were worth saving."

My confusion must have been evident because she continued, "Everyone deserves a second chance, even kidnappers. So, here's the deal. You walk away from this, and we forget it ever happened. Or you can keep trying and face the consequences."

"You're giving me a choice?" I asked, incredulous.

"Call it an act of mercy," she said, standing up and tossing a few bills on the table to cover her coffee. "But don't mistake it for weakness."

As she walked away, I felt a strange mix of relief and frustration. She was letting me go, but why? I followed her out of the café, keeping a safe distance. She led me to a secluded alley where The Specter waited, his silhouette barely visible in the shadows.

"You've got guts, I'll give you that," he said, his voice low and menacing. "But if you ever come near her again, I won't be so forgiving."

"Why?" I asked, genuinely curious. "Why not just kill me and be done with it?"

The Specter stepped forward, his face still obscured. "Because she believes in second chances, even for people like you. And for her sake, I'm willing to give you one."

I looked at Lisa, who stood silently beside him, her expression unreadable. "Why do you care?" I asked her.

"Because everyone deserves a chance to change," she said simply. "Even you."

The Specter placed a hand on her shoulder, a silent gesture of support. "Now go," he commanded. "Before I change my mind."

I turned and walked away, my mind racing. They had seen through my plan from the start, yet they chose to let me live. It was a strange and humbling experience. As I left the alley, I couldn't help but wonder what kind of person could turn a kidnapping into a lesson on redemption.

Maybe, just maybe, there was hope for me after all.

prompt: Sherlock Holmes and John Watson are roped into running a Haunted House attraction, but between a biting dragon costume, candy floss chaos, and Sherlock’s disdain for unflattering jumpers, things quickly spiral into absurdity.

“Stop moaning and be grateful,” John Watson said. “At least we’re inside, which means we’re not quite as cold as we would be otherwise.”
Sherlock Holmes, who was wearing a skeleton outfit, groaned. “It’s not like the Haunted House is a proper insulated building, it’s just a couple of sheds, plus the reindeer stable, converted for the occasion.” He looked critically at John. “Is that ghost costume padded? You look bigger than you did yesterday.”
“I’m wearing a thick jumper underneath my sheet. The one you told me was extremely unflattering. Which it may be, but it’s also warm.” John tried, and failed, to keep the smugness out of his voice.
Sherlock was about to reply when the Tannoy blared.
Places everyone. The gates open in ten minutes.
Together they headed towards the Haunted House. Partway they passed a dragon which was lying on its side, groaning, and waving its legs rather ineffectively in the air.
“Don’t worry,” John said cheerfully, “we’ll let Greg know you need some help.”
There was what sounded like muffled swearing from the dragon, which tried to kick John with one of its back legs. John moved out of its way and said, “Temper, temper!”
When they reached the Haunted House, they found Anderson standing mournfully outside.
“Someone eaten all your apples?” John asked.
“I wish,” Anderson replied. “No, I’m stuck out here, making toffee apples in the cold, while Sally gets to be inside.”
“Should have worn a woolly hat!”
Once inside, John greeted Sally with, “I hear you’ve been promoted to an inside job.”
“Yes,” she agreed. “It gets quite windy outside which was blowing the candy floss everywhere.”
“As I thought,” Sherlock said. “It wasn’t concern for your welfare, but not wanting to lose candy floss.”
“I’m not bothered about the reasoning. I’m inside and I don’t have to listen to Anderson’s moaning.”
At that point Greg arrived. “Right,” he said, “remember you’re to make them squeal with fright, not cry with fear. It’s to be a pleasurable experience. We don’t want any more complaints.”
“Whose been complaining?” Sherlock asked.
“It wasn’t you. Apparently the dragon bit someone yesterday. Some kid decided to put their head in the dragon’s mouth to see what was there. And the dragon closed its mouth. Forcibly. There were tooth marks on the kid’s neck.”
“Dragon ate our Albert!” Sally said.
“What? How do you know the kid was called Albert?” Sherlock asked.
“Never mind,” John said. “Oh, speaking of dragons, it’s fallen over and can’t get back up again.”
“It will,” Greg said. “I’ll prod it with St George’s spear.”
“And why is there a dragon? They’re not traditional Hallowe’en creatures.”
“Mycroft got a cheap George and the Dragon costume. We’re not using the George part, although the spear is quite useful. The dragon costume needs adjusting. At the moment Seb’s at the front and Jim’s at the back. Molly thinks it would work better with Jim at the front, but Seb doesn’t fit in the back half. I must be off, dragon to right, punters to welcome. Have a good day, folks!”
With that Greg departed, ignoring the various rude words flung in his direction.

John Watson had been many things in his life—soldier, doctor, and flatmate to the world's most insufferable consulting detective. But as he stood in the center of 221B Baker Street, surrounded by cobweb decorations and a dragon costume that looked suspiciously like it had been dragged through a hedge, he found himself confronting a new role: Haunted House manager.

"Absolutely not," Sherlock declared, holding up a garish orange jumper adorned with a grinning pumpkin. "There are limits to what even I will tolerate for the sake of an investigation."

John sighed, rubbing his temples. "It's for the kids, Sherlock. And it's not an investigation. Mrs. Hudson asked us to help because the community center's short-staffed."

"Semantics," Sherlock muttered, but he reluctantly pulled the jumper over his head, looking like he'd rather be dissecting a corpse.

The dragon costume lay ominously on the sofa, and John eyed it warily. "Does it bite?" he asked, half-joking.

Sherlock shot him a withering look. "Don't be ridiculous, John. It doesn't—" He stopped mid-sentence as the dragon's head snapped towards him with a mechanical growl. "Oh, for heaven's sake."

"Looks like it does," John said with a smirk. "Come on, let's get this show on the road."

The community center was a buzz of activity. Children in various states of costume chaos darted around, high on sugar and excitement. Sherlock's dragon costume, now safely worn by a teenager who seemed to have no issues with its mechanical tendencies, was a hit. 

Sherlock, meanwhile, was manning the 'Mad Scientist's Laboratory,' which mostly involved glaring at anyone who approached his station. John was in charge of the candy floss machine, a task he quickly regretted as pink sticky clouds began to envelop him.

"Sherlock," John called out, trying to disentangle himself from the sugary mess, "a little help here?"

Sherlock glanced over, his expression a mix of amusement and disdain. "John, you look like a yeti caught in a candy floss avalanche."

"Very funny," John grumbled, but couldn't help a chuckle. "Just, can you—" 

Before he could finish, a small child tugged on Sherlock's jumper. "Mr. Dragon, can I have some candy floss, please?"

Sherlock's eyes softened—a rare sight. "Of course," he said, taking the child's hand and leading them over to the machine.

As the night wore on, the chaos only increased. The dragon costume had somehow ended up in the haunted maze, terrorizing teenagers and causing several to flee in exaggerated horror. Sherlock's jumper had acquired a few new stains, courtesy of overenthusiastic children with sticky hands. And John, well, he was still fighting a losing battle with the candy floss machine.

story_b:
Sherlock Holmes stood in the dimly lit Haunted House, flickering lanterns casting eerie shadows across his face. The scent of candy floss mingled with the crisp autumn air, creating a peculiar ambiance. Beside him, John Watson adjusted his own ill-fitting jumper, muttering, "I feel like a walking pumpkin in this."

"This is hardly the case of the century, John," Sherlock quipped, tugging at the neckline of his own garish jumper, emblazoned with a garish cartoon bat. "These jumpers aren't known for their flattering fit."

John chuckled, "But it might be the most colorful."

The Haunted House was bustling with visitors, children giggling nervously as they approached the entrance. Suddenly, a commotion erupted from the corner where the dragon costume lurked, its elongated neck snapping playfully at unsuspecting visitors.

"That costume has a mind of its own," John remarked, watching as a child shrieked with delight rather than fear.

Sherlock rolled his eyes. "I think I'd be far better suited to being a dragon tamer," he said dryly, marching over to the costume. He bent down, inspecting the mechanism within. "Ah, faulty wiring," he deduced, swiftly untangling the mess. "Elementary."

As he stood, the dragon head gave an affectionate nip at his shoulder, earning a reluctant smile from Sherlock. "Quite the bite you've got there," he said, patting the costume's snout.

Meanwhile, the candy floss machine began to emit a strange whirring sound, clouds of pink sugar swirling like mischievous spirits. A young girl nearby yelped as her hair became entangled in the sticky mess. Sherlock sighed, striding over with determination.

"Hold still," he instructed, deftly untangling the candy floss from the girl’s hair. "This is more convoluted than any case file."

John joined him, trying to suppress his laughter. "You look like you're in a story by Lewis Carroll."

"More like H.G. Wells, given the technology involved," Sherlock retorted, a hint of amusement in his eyes.

The girl beamed at him, "You're a real-life hero, Mr. Dragon!"

Sherlock straightened, a rare, genuine smile tugging at his lips. "Hardly," he replied, but the warmth in his voice betrayed his pleasure.

As the evening wore on, the chaos continued. The dragon costume snapped at visitors with playful mischief, and the candy floss machine occasionally sputtered out puffs of sugar. Yet, amidst the absurdity, Sherlock found himself unexpectedly enjoying the whimsical nature of it all.

John watched him, noting the subtle changes in his demeanor. "Perhaps a cape would suit you better, Sherlock," he suggested, gesturing to the jumper. 

"If you ever suggest I wear that jumper again, John, I will personally see to its destruction," Sherlock declared with mock severity.

John laughed, clapping him on the shoulder. "Deal."

As the Haunted House finally quieted down, Sherlock and John stood side by side, surveying the aftermath of their adventure. The lanterns flickered, casting a cozy glow over the scene.

"Not the worst way to spend an evening," John admitted.

Sherlock nodded, a touch of contentment in his voice. "No, not the worst at all."

prompt: Sherlock Holmes and John Watson are roped into running a Haunted House attraction, but between a biting dragon costume, candy floss chaos, and Sherlock’s disdain for unflattering jumpers, things quickly spiral into absurdity.
ground_truth:
“Stop moaning and be grateful,” John Watson said. “At least we’re inside, which means we’re not quite as cold as we would be otherwise.”
Sherlock Holmes, who was wearing a skeleton outfit, groaned. “It’s not like the Haunted House is a proper insulated building, it’s just a couple of sheds, plus the reindeer stable, converted for the occasion.” He looked critically at John. “Is that ghost costume padded? You look bigger than you did yesterday.”
“I’m wearing a thick jumper underneath my sheet. The one you told me was extremely unflattering. Which it may be, but it’s also warm.” John tried, and failed, to keep the smugness out of his voice.
Sherlock was about to reply when the Tannoy blared.
Places everyone. The gates open in ten minutes.
Together they headed towards the Haunted House. Partway they passed a dragon which was lying on its side, groaning, and waving its legs rather ineffectively in the air.
“Don’t worry,” John said cheerfully, “we’ll let Greg know you need some help.”
There was what sounded like muffled swearing from the dragon, which tried to kick John with one of its back legs. John moved out of its way and said, “Temper, temper!”
When they reached the Haunted House, they found Anderson standing mournfully outside.
“Someone eaten all your apples?” John asked.
“I wish,” Anderson replied. “No, I’m stuck out here, making toffee apples in the cold, while Sally gets to be inside.”
“Should have worn a woolly hat!”
Once inside, John greeted Sally with, “I hear you’ve been promoted to an inside job.”
“Yes,” she agreed. “It gets quite windy outside which was blowing the candy floss everywhere.”
“As I thought,” Sherlock said. “It wasn’t concern for your welfare, but not wanting to lose candy floss.”
“I’m not bothered about the reasoning. I’m inside and I don’t have to listen to Anderson’s moaning.”
At that point Greg arrived. “Right,” he said, “remember you’re to make them squeal with fright, not cry with fear. It’s to be a pleasurable experience. We don’t want any more complaints.”
“Whose been complaining?” Sherlock asked.
“It wasn’t you. Apparently the dragon bit someone yesterday. Some kid decided to put their head in the dragon’s mouth to see what was there. And the dragon closed its mouth. Forcibly. There were tooth marks on the kid’s neck.”
“Dragon ate our Albert!” Sally said.
“What? How do you know the kid was called Albert?” Sherlock asked.
“Never mind,” John said. “Oh, speaking of dragons, it’s fallen over and can’t get back up again.”
“It will,” Greg said. “I’ll prod it with St George’s spear.”
“And why is there a dragon? They’re not traditional Hallowe’en creatures.”
“Mycroft got a cheap George and the Dragon costume. We’re not using the George part, although the spear is quite useful. The dragon costume needs adjusting. At the moment Seb’s at the front and Jim’s at the back. Molly thinks it would work better with Jim at the front, but Seb doesn’t fit in the back half. I must be off, dragon to right, punters to welcome. Have a good day, folks!”
With that Greg departed, ignoring the various rude words flung in his direction.
story_a:
John Watson had been many things in his life—soldier, doctor, and flatmate to the world's most insufferable consulting detective. But as he stood in the center of 221B Baker Street, surrounded by cobweb decorations and a dragon costume that looked suspiciously like it had been dragged through a hedge, he found himself confronting a new role: Haunted House manager.

"Absolutely not," Sherlock declared, holding up a garish orange jumper adorned with a grinning pumpkin. "There are limits to what even I will tolerate for the sake of an investigation."

John sighed, rubbing his temples. "It's for the kids, Sherlock. And it's not an investigation. Mrs. Hudson asked us to help because the community center's short-staffed."

"Semantics," Sherlock muttered, but he reluctantly pulled the jumper over his head, looking like he'd rather be dissecting a corpse.

The dragon costume lay ominously on the sofa, and John eyed it warily. "Does it bite?" he asked, half-joking.

Sherlock shot him a withering look. "Don't be ridiculous, John. It doesn't—" He stopped mid-sentence as the dragon's head snapped towards him with a mechanical growl. "Oh, for heaven's sake."

"Looks like it does," John said with a smirk. "Come on, let's get this show on the road."

The community center was a buzz of activity. Children in various states of costume chaos darted around, high on sugar and excitement. Sherlock's dragon costume, now safely worn by a teenager who seemed to have no issues with its mechanical tendencies, was a hit. 

Sherlock, meanwhile, was manning the 'Mad Scientist's Laboratory,' which mostly involved glaring at anyone who approached his station. John was in charge of the candy floss machine, a task he quickly regretted as pink sticky clouds began to envelop him.

"Sherlock," John called out, trying to disentangle himself from the sugary mess, "a little help here?"

Sherlock glanced over, his expression a mix of amusement and disdain. "John, you look like a yeti caught in a candy floss avalanche."

"Very funny," John grumbled, but couldn't help a chuckle. "Just, can you—" 

Before he could finish, a small child tugged on Sherlock's jumper. "Mr. Dragon, can I have some candy floss, please?"

Sherlock's eyes softened—a rare sight. "Of course," he said, taking the child's hand and leading them over to the machine.

As the night wore on, the chaos only increased. The dragon costume had somehow ended up in the haunted maze, terrorizing teenagers and causing several to flee in exaggerated horror. Sherlock's jumper had acquired a few new stains, courtesy of overenthusiastic children with sticky hands. And John, well, he was still fighting a losing battle with the candy floss machine.

But amidst the absurdity, there were moments—fleeting, but precious—where laughter rang out and smiles were shared. Sherlock, despite his grumbling, had a glimmer of enjoyment in his eyes. John, tired but happy, couldn't deny the warmth that filled his heart seeing Sherlock engage with the children, even if it was in his own peculiar way.

As the night came to an end, Sherlock turned to John, a rare smile playing on his lips. "Perhaps there's something to be said for unflattering jumpers and candy floss chaos after all."

John laughed, clapping Sherlock on the shoulder. "Happy Halloween, Sherlock."

"Happy Halloween, John."
story_b:
"I fail to see the appeal of scaring people with costumes," Sherlock grumbled as he stood at the entrance of the Haunted House, arms crossed and a frown etched onto his face.

John Watson, who had somehow been persuaded to accompany Sherlock in this endeavor, smirked. "Oh, come on, Sherlock. It's for charity. Besides, it's not every day you get to see a dragon costume with a mind of its own."

Indeed, the dragon costume was an impressive—if somewhat defective—creation. Designed to loom menacingly over guests as they entered the house, it had unfortunately developed a habit of snapping its jaws at anyone who got too close. Which, as it turned out, included Sherlock. 

"Watch it, Sherlock, the dragon's biting again!" John called, barely concealing his amusement as the dragon's head lurched forward, narrowly missing Sherlock's ear.

Sherlock sidestepped with a huff. "This is ridiculous," he muttered, adjusting the unflattering jumper that Mrs. Hudson had insisted he wear for the occasion. It was an eye-searing shade of orange, adorned with a pattern that vaguely resembled cobwebs. 

"At least it matches the dragon's scales," John quipped, earning himself a withering glare from Sherlock.

Inside, the haunted house was a whirlwind of chaos. Fog machines belched clouds of mist, while strobe lights flickered erratically. The air was filled with the sounds of creaking floorboards and eerie wails, punctuated by the occasional shriek from a startled visitor.

In the corner, a candy floss machine was churning out a sticky, sugary mess. Somehow, the floss had managed to escape its confines and was now clinging to every available surface, creating a web of pastel-colored chaos. 

"John, the candy floss is staging a coup," Sherlock observed dryly as they passed by, lifting a strand of pink fluff off his shoulder with disdain.

"Looks like it's winning," John replied, trying to stifle his laughter as he watched a group of children attempt to untangle themselves from the sticky trap.

The evening continued in a similar vein, with the dragon costume causing havoc and the candy floss becoming an unintentional attraction in its own right. As the night wore on, even Sherlock seemed to relent slightly, his irritation giving way to a grudging acceptance of the absurdity around him.

Finally, as the last guests trickled out and the haunted house began to wind down, John turned to Sherlock with a grin. "Admit it, you had fun."

Sherlock hesitated, then sighed. "It was... not entirely without merit," he conceded, though his tone suggested he was loath to admit even that much.

John chuckled, clapping him on the back. "See? Told you. And look on the bright side—we survived a dragon attack and a candy floss rebellion. I'd call that a success."

Sherlock's lips twitched in what might have been the ghost of a smile. "I suppose," he said, finally allowing himself a moment of levity. "Though next time, John, you're wearing the jumper."

With that, they stepped back into the cool night air, leaving behind the chaos of the haunted house but carrying with them the memory of an evening that, despite its absurdities, had proven unexpectedly entertaining.

story_b:
"John, this is absurd," Sherlock Holmes grumbled, tugging at the hem of an offensively orange jumper that declared in bold black letters: 'Official Haunted House Guide'. The Haunted House attraction loomed behind them, a haphazard amalgamation of creaky floorboards, fake cobwebs, and the unmistakable scent of candy floss gone rogue.

"Think of it as a case, Sherlock," John Watson replied, attempting to maintain a semblance of order. "A mystery to solve. Besides, Mrs. Hudson insisted we help her friend."

Sherlock sighed dramatically. "If by 'mystery' you mean managing a malfunctioning dragon costume and corralling sugar-fueled children, then yes, a riveting case indeed."

As if on cue, a child shrieked as the dragon costume—previously suspended in eerie stillness—lurched forward with a mechanical growl. Its eyes glowed an unsettling red, and its wings flapped with a mind of their own, sending a gust of air through the room.

"Fantastic," Sherlock muttered. "The dragon costume's gone rogue."

John chuckled. "You fix the dragon, I'll distract the visitors."

With a theatrical roll of his eyes, Sherlock approached the dragon, examining the machinery with his usual analytical precision. Meanwhile, John gathered the children around him, launching into an impromptu ghost story. "Once upon a time, in a house just like this one..."

Sherlock focused on the dragon's wiring, his fingers deftly navigating the tangled mess. "Simple mechanics," he murmured, disconnecting a few wires and reconnecting them with a sharp click. The dragon stilled, its eyes dimming to a harmless yellow.

"How's it going, Sherlock?" John called, his ghost story reaching its crescendo with the kids hanging on his every word.

"It's as fixed as it can be," Sherlock replied, turning back to the crowd. "Though I suspect our issues stem from more mischievous roots."

As the attraction continued, Sherlock's gaze flitted around the room. A group of children, suspiciously giggling in the corner, caught his attention. One child held a remote control, its antenna pointed toward the dragon.

"Ah, our culprits," Sherlock said, striding over with the jumper flapping ridiculously. "Ingenious, but you'll have to try harder to fool me."

The children burst into laughter, their prank exposed. "You caught us, Mr. Holmes!" one of them exclaimed.

John joined them, a broad grin on his face. "Looks like we've been outsmarted by children, Sherlock."

Sherlock huffed, though amusement tugged at the corners of his mouth. "A clever ruse. Perhaps I underestimated the complexity of this case."

"Perhaps you did," John agreed, clapping Sherlock on the back. "Now, let's finish this day without further chaos, shall we?"

By the end of the night, the Haunted House had returned to its charming disarray, and the visitors departed with tales of their own. As they locked up, Sherlock caught sight of his reflection in a mirror, the garish jumper still in place.

"Admit it, Sherlock," John teased, "you enjoyed it more than you thought."

Sherlock sighed, a rare smile gracing his features. "Perhaps. But don't expect me to wear this jumper again."

John laughed, leading the way out. "Come on, let's go home before the dragon decides to take another bite."

prompt: A photographer becomes obsessed with the haunting eyes of a young girl he captures on film, unaware that her mother is plagued by vivid nightmares of her daughter being watched, dissected, and photographed by strangers.
ground_truth:
The girl with the purple eyes did not like having her picture taken. She scowled into the camera with alarming intensity.

“Smile,” the photographer said, flashing his own toothy grin.

Her face remained unchanged. No one had asked how she felt being cornered by a stranger, or if she wanted to smile, and scowling was her only means of protest.

The girl with the purple eyes didn’t actually have purple eyes—that’s just how they looked to her classmates. Really they were deep-blue. The purple came from them being sunken, dark underneath, like a smudged plum or bruises: the combination of inherited memory—generations and generations of purple-eyed women—and many sleepless nights spent coughing, small lungs gasping for air.

She got her lungs from her father, who had suffered from asthma as well. Growing up, he was thin, probably from the lack of oxygen, breathing in just enough to survive and nothing more. Not enough to thrive or grow or run the way that most boys do, and so he remained small and devoted himself to studying biology and later, medicine. He was different from the other men in his family, and perhaps it was his smallness that made him kind.

The purple-eyed women on her mother’s side began generations ago. Years of stored fears, doubts, holding of breath so that Dad doesn’t hear you under the bed; the acceptance that even if he doesn’t hear you, he knows exactly where you are; the truth that there is no escape. Small girls’ bodies covered in fingerprints, dealt with harshly, like overworked clay.

It’s the lack of air that makes for purple eyes, whether it be from fear, asthma, dreams of drowning, or the inherited memory of what’s mine is theirs, especially if what’s mine is feminine and soft—the remembering through mothers and mothers and mothers.

After taking her photo, the toothy man, Wes, gave her a nod. While he wished he could’ve coaxed a smile out of this last one, it had been a pretty successful day. Two hours of wrangling a pre-K class into solo photos outside on the playground without a single tantrum or tear shed was success in his book.

Wes’s standard of success had changed since his art school days. Back then he spent hours shooting smoke clouds on film, or nude men in black and white. Back then success meant he had been invited onto a shoot with some obscure creative vision or had scored a free drink at a bar, sent over by someone mysterious, attractive, older. He never could have guessed that elementary-class photos would end up paying his bills, or that he would learn how to make four-year-olds smile with his exaggerated facial expressions, almost without fail.

When he got home Wes popped a bag of ready-to-steam frozen edamame into the microwave and stared at the photo of that girl, the one with eyes so deep he felt they might fall right into her head.

Damn.

She was only four or five, with bangs that cut straight across her forehead, her hair pulled back at the nape of her neck into a loose ponytail. She wore a smocked blue cotton dress that popped against her olive skin. It was an eerie photo, and this was one of those rare moments when he looked at his work and remembered what it felt like to be an artist. Suddenly, he was glad she hadn’t smiled. This made for a much better photo. Maybe not something her parents would want to hang on the fridge, but still.


Nicole pulled up thirty minutes late, screeching to a halt in front of the school. Thirty minutes late meant she would have to retrieve Ella from the office.

“We have a three-strike system, okay?” said Ms. Smith, the school’s head of administration. She was a petite lady with a southern accent, always wearing a full face of makeup, always in heels. She was someone whom Nicole would have avoided at first glance, but two months into the school year Ms. Smith had proven to be kind, warm-hearted, and welcoming while Ella and her mom learned what it meant to attend St. Ignatius Day School.

“Don’t fret about it today. I know how hard it can be with traffic and all. It’s just a formality,” she said, handing Ella’s mom a hot-pink “tardy slip.”

Despite Ms. Smith’s reassurance, the hot-pink slip certainly felt like more than just a formality. As she strode down the hall to the office, every teacher she passed stared her down, giving her a disdainful once-over. She folded the piece of paper and shoved it into her purse.

Don’t you care about your child? Are you completely self-absorbed? Don’t you know how traumatizing it is to be forgotten? Think of how this could impact her future.

She added her own harsh words to their disapproving glances.

Quite honestly, she had forgotten Ella. Well, not forgotten entirely—she had lost track of time. She had been drifting in and out of sleep, and suddenly it was 2:55, leaving her just five minutes to make the almost thirty-minute drive to Ella’s school.

She hadn’t taken the time to put on something more “adult,” or even more “mom,” and now she walked briskly through the hallway in Ugg slippers and mismatched pajamas.

On the way home Ella and her mom stopped for Chick-fil-A, a rare indulgence that they decided they had both earned. Ella got a fried-chicken sandwich and a Sprite. She ate about half her sandwich before tucking the rest away in the pocket of the seat in front of her, saving it for later. She took a pull of Sprite through the straw and nodded the way little kids do when they are exceptionally pleased with their choice in beverage.

Ella caught her mom’s eye in the rearview mirror and scrunched up her face in a smile.

Relief swept through Nicole’s shoulders and chest. She could almost cry.

“Today a man with very white teeth took our pictures without asking,” Ella said.

“I know, hon. I told you about school pictures today. That’s why you wore your dress, remember?”

“I think I forgot,” Ella stated matter-of-factly, taking another swig of Sprite.

“That’s okay, Ella. Hey, on our way home I’m going to run into Walgreens, okay? You can stay in the car and finish your Sprite.”

Ella nodded.


Wes grabbed his gym bag from the bench by the door and threw it over his shoulder, digging around in his jacket pocket for his car keys. At thirty-three, he had promised himself that he would never fall victim to that soft, midthirties dad-bod that so many of his friends had grown into, so he worked out often and ate “clean.” Sure, dad-bods were fine for them—most of them settling into complacent, accepting relationships—but he could do better.

On his way to the gym he stopped by the Walgreens to pick up some Advil, Irish Springs body wash, and a Gatorade Zero. Out of habit he waved at the TV monitor that greeted him, and the tiny mirror image version of him on the monitor waved back.

A woman walked in just as he finished waving, and Wes caught a glimpse of her in the monitor. He was transported. Her eyes were sad, sunken, dark, purple underneath, almost like someone had taken a fist to each of them. It was the second time that day Wes had seen eyes like those. His eyes followed her to the prescription counter, until the rotating display of reading glasses blocked her from view.

That evening Wes fell asleep on the couch while watching Spencer, his favorite film about Princess Diana. His dreams began with the haunted face of Princess Di as she appeared in the film, played by Kristen Stewart, withering away under the watchful eye of the royal family. Suddenly she was joined by the purple-eyed girl and the purple-eyed woman he had seen earlier that day. The three of them followed him everywhere he went—the gym, the grocery store, the car wash—but in a strange turn of events, he realized that it was he who was following them. He caught their reflections in windows, TV screens, puddles in the street. He stalked them with his camera, like a member of the paparazzi, desperate to get the right angle, the perfect photo. They did not say anything to him or acknowledge that he was there. He followed them all the way to their house in the English countryside, and then he woke up.


Ella’s dad worked late that night, so Ella and her mom agreed to watch a few episodes of Little Bear while Ella had a breathing treatment. The mask fit over her mouth and nose with a blue elastic strap that went behind her head, like the kind they show you on an airplane “in case of a loss of cabin pressure.” By now Ella was used to the sounds and smells of albuterol being pumped into her lungs and she relaxed into her beanbag chair, watching while Little Bear scooped the moon up into his bucket of water. One hour later, Ella was showered and tucked into bed wearing her polyester blue Cinderella nightgown.

“Goodnight, Ella. Sweet dreams,” her mom said, pulling her door almost to a close.

Then Nicole crawled into her own bed, allowing her feet to stretch as far as they could down into the cool cotton sheets, allowing herself to spread starfish for a moment before turning over onto her left side into a small fetal position.

It would be a late night for Michael, which meant a less than ideal night’s sleep for her. She would be on edge until he got home. She tried waiting up and opened her copy of The House of the Spirits, a book she had reread more times than she could count. Somehow she found it comforting. Something about the stored-up generations of motherhood, the trauma manifested in physical bodies, the brokenness, but also the slow growth and healing that rolled through the Trueba and del Valle families. It made her feel hopeful. She drifted in and out of sleep. Eventually, she slipped into deep sleep, the kind filled with rhythmic breathing and vivid dreams.

She dreamed that she was wandering the hallways of a big creaky house with heavy curtains and doors. She didn’t recognize the house but seemed to know exactly where to go. She was small again and wore a white nightgown smattered with blue and pink flowers. She was looking for something.

She found her way to the kitchen and paused outside the closed door. There were voices on the other side and she could see the lights on, glowing underneath. They were cold, blue, like hospital lights, or the kind associated with an alien abduction—not like the lights of the kitchen she knew. The voices she heard sounded sterile. She didn’t want to open the door because she didn’t want anyone to see her, so she peeked through the keyhole and let out a silent scream.

Splayed out on the kitchen table was Nicole’s Ella, though in this strange world she and Ella both looked about five—not possibly mother and daughter. Ella was spread wide like a butchered animal, two men bent over her little body—men rummaging around in her abdomen, poking and prodding with long metal prongs, wringing out her insides like wet paper towels, slicing through her soft belly and cracking open her chest cavity. They whispered and laughed. They seemed to be searching for something inside her, like pearl divers slicing open oyster shells, unbothered by oyster flesh and juice.

Ella’s mom could hear every snap and squelch as the men made themselves familiar with Ella’s insides, as if the awful sounds were being broadcast over a loud speaker. Then one of the men pulled out a camera with a big flashbulb on top and started snapping pictures of Ella’s body from all different angles, contorted, bloodied, splayed open, her eyes empty and deep. Every flash lit the room like a burst of lightning, and the snap of the lens made Ella’s mom feel sick—the snap, flash, snap, flash over and over again, like a strobe light.

This was more than Nicole could bear, and she let out another scream, though this one was not silent. It was loud, desperate to be heard.

Suddenly she was awake, catching the end of her own scream, which had followed her from nightmare into consciousness. For a moment she didn’t know where she was. She was enveloped in dense, still darkness. She felt a small rustle and realized she was in Ella’s room, kneeling beside her bed. She felt her own face, wet with tears; felt her arms and shoulders, her chest, making sure she was in her adult body again.

Then she felt Ella’s arm, gently; her shoulders, her head. She was warm, small and whole, still in her Cinderella nightgown, breathing deeply. Her eyes fluttered open.

“Mom, did you have a bad dream?” Ella asked, her voice full of sleep. She stroked her mom’s head gently, the way someone might pet a wild animal or baby bird.

“Ella, I did. I had a really bad dream.”

“Do you want to get in? To help you sleep?” Ella lifted her comforter a bit, showing the wide expanse of unoccupied twin bed to her left.

“For a little bit. Just until Dad gets home.” Nicole answered, climbing into bed.

The first time I saw her eyes, I was crouched behind the lens of my Leica, adjusting the focus to capture the delicate interplay of light and shadow in the crowded marketplace. It was late afternoon, and the sun cast a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors of the vendor stalls and the faces of the people drifting through the narrow aisles. I was just a visitor, passing through this small town on my way to nowhere in particular, drawn by the promise of capturing the essence of everyday life in my photographs.

Then I saw her. She stood apart from the bustling crowd, a still figure in a sea of movement. Her dark hair framed a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, and her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazed directly into the lens as if she could see through it, into me. They were eyes that spoke of wisdom and sorrow far beyond her years, and I knew in that moment that I had to capture them.

I clicked the shutter once, twice, three times, unable to tear myself away from the intensity of her gaze. It was only when a woman, presumably her mother, hurried over and took her by the hand that I lowered my camera. The woman glanced at me briefly, her expression one of guarded suspicion, before leading the girl away. But those eyes stayed with me, burned into my memory and, more importantly, onto my film.

Back in my small rented room, I developed the photos in the makeshift darkroom I had set up in the bathroom. The image of the girl emerged slowly, the chemicals revealing the stark contrast of her pale face against the dark backdrop of the market. Her eyes, even in black and white, seemed to hold a depth that was almost supernatural. I found myself staring at the photograph long after it had dried, tracing the lines of her face with my finger, lost in the mystery of who she was and what her eyes were trying to tell me.

Days turned into weeks, and I couldn't shake the image of the girl from my mind. I returned to the marketplace every day, hoping to see her again, but she was never there. I asked around, describing her to the vendors and the regulars, but no one seemed to know who she was. It was as if she had appeared out of nowhere, a ghost haunting my thoughts and my art.

My obsession with the girl began to consume me. I spent hours each night developing and re-developing the same photograph, trying to tease out more details, to understand the story behind those eyes. I started to dream about her, vivid and unsettling dreams where she would appear in different places—standing in the corner of my room, sitting at the edge of my bed, always watching me with that unblinking gaze.

One night, as I was poring over the photograph yet again, a knock on the door startled me. I opened it to find the girl's mother standing there, her face pale and drawn, her eyes filled with a mixture of fear and desperation.

"Please," she said, her voice trembling. "You have to stop."

"Stop what?" I asked, genuinely confused.

"Taking pictures of my daughter," she replied. "You've been following us, haven't you?"

"No, I—" I began, but she cut me off.

"I can feel it," she said, her voice rising. "Every night, I see her in my dreams, watched by strangers, dissected by their eyes and their cameras. It's driving me mad. You have to stop."

Her words stunned me into silence. I had no idea that my obsession had been affecting her so deeply, that she had been experiencing the same nightmares that plagued me. I wanted to explain, to apologize, but the intensity of her emotion left me speechless.

"Please," she repeated, tears welling up in her eyes. "Let us be."

She turned and walked away before I could respond, leaving me standing in the doorway, the weight of her words heavy on my shoulders. I closed the door and returned to my darkroom, staring at the photograph of the girl one last time before tucking it away in a drawer.

I didn't go back to the marketplace after that. I packed my things and moved on, hoping to leave the haunting eyes and the nightmares behind. But even now, years later, I can still see her face in my mind, those eyes staring out at me from the depths of my memory, a reminder of the unintended consequences of my obsession.

In the years that followed, I traveled far and wide, capturing images of people and places, each photograph a testament to the world as I saw it. But no matter how many faces I photographed, none ever held the same power, the same haunting beauty, as the eyes of that young girl in the marketplace.

As time passed, I found myself returning to that small town, drawn by an inexplicable need to confront the past. The marketplace was still there, much the same as I remembered it, the same vendors selling their wares, the same vibrant energy filling the air. But the girl and her mother were nowhere to be found.

I wandered through the narrow aisles, my camera hanging heavy around my neck, feeling a strange sense of loss and longing. I had hoped that coming back here would bring some sort of closure, but instead, it only deepened the mystery. I felt like a ghost, drifting through a place that no longer held any answers.

It was late afternoon when I stumbled upon a small photography shop tucked away in a quiet corner of the marketplace. Curious, I stepped inside, the bell above the door tinkling softly. The shop was filled with old cameras and photographs, a treasure trove of memories captured on film.

As I browsed the shelves, my eyes were drawn to a photograph hanging on the wall. It was a portrait of a young girl, her dark hair framing a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazing directly into the camera. My heart skipped a beat as I realized it was the same girl I had photographed all those years ago.

I turned to the shopkeeper, an elderly man with a kind smile and a twinkle in his eye.

"Who is she?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

The shopkeeper looked at the photograph and then back at me, his smile fading.

"She was my granddaughter," he said softly. "She passed away many years ago."

I felt a lump form in my throat as I processed his words. The girl, the haunting eyes, the nightmares—it all made sense now. She had been trying to tell me something, to reach out from beyond the grave, and I had been too blind to see it.

"I'm sorry," I said, my voice choked with emotion. "I didn't know."

The shopkeeper nodded, his eyes filled with a sadness that mirrored my own.

"She was special," he said. "Her eyes saw things that others couldn't. She had a gift, but it also brought her great pain."

I felt a deep sense of guilt wash over me, realizing that my obsession with her had only added to that pain. I wanted to make amends, to find some way to honor her memory, but I didn't know how.

"May I buy the photograph?" I asked, hoping that having it would bring some measure of closure.

The shopkeeper shook his head. "It's not for sale," he said gently. "But you can have it. She would have wanted you to have it."

I took the photograph from the wall, feeling its weight in my hands. It was more than just a picture; it was a connection to a past I could never fully understand, a reminder of the consequences of my actions and the haunting beauty of those eyes.

As I left the shop, I felt a strange sense of peace settle over me. The girl's eyes would always be with me, a silent witness to my journey and a testament to the power of a single moment captured on film. And in that moment, I knew that my obsession had not been in vain. It had led me to a deeper understanding of myself and the world around me, and for that, I was grateful.

I walked through the marketplace one last time, the photograph clutched tightly in my hand. The sun was setting, casting a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors and the shadows. I raised my camera and took one final picture, capturing the essence of the place that had changed my life forever. And as I did, I felt the weight of the past lift from my shoulders, replaced by a sense of hope and possibility.

In the end, it was not the photograph of the girl that haunted me, but the lesson she had taught me: that every image, every moment, holds a story waiting to be discovered, and that sometimes, the most powerful stories are the ones that we least expect.

The fog rolled in thick, shrouding the coastal town in a blanket of gray that seemed to dull the edges of reality. It was the kind of morning where time felt suspended, as if the world held its breath waiting for something to tip the scales. In his dimly lit studio, surrounded by vintage cameras and the sharp scent of developing chemicals, Adrian Hart was already lost in his latest obsession.

The photograph lay before him, a black-and-white portrait of a young girl with eyes that seemed to pierce through the paper. They were pools of shadow that seemed to hold secrets untold, drawing him in with an intensity that left him breathless. Each time he glanced at them, he felt a peculiar sensation, as though the eyes were alive, watching him, understanding him in ways that no one else could.

Adrian's fingers brushed over the photograph, the texture of the paper rough against his skin. He had captured her by chance on a breezy afternoon, the sun breaking through clouds just long enough to cast a halo around her in the park. She had been standing alone, her gaze fixed on something distant, and he had been unable to resist the pull of the light, the way it danced in her eyes.

He had not intended to take her picture. His focus had been on the landscape, on the way the shadows played against the aged stone fountain. But when he developed the film, her image emerged like a specter, haunting and beautiful, demanding his attention.

Across town, in a small house nestled at the end of a quiet street, Clara sat bolt upright in her bed, the remnants of a nightmare clinging to her like cobwebs. Her breath came in ragged gasps, her heart pounding a frantic rhythm against her ribs. She pressed a hand to her chest, willing it to calm, to slow, but the images from her dream swirled in her mind, refusing to dissipate.

In the dream, her daughter, Lily, had been standing in a field of wildflowers, her dress a splash of color against the muted tones of the landscape. Clara had watched, unable to move, as shadows crept closer, faceless figures with cameras and notebooks, their eyes hidden behind dark glasses. They circled Lily, their presence oppressive, and Clara had screamed, a soundless cry that echoed in the void.

Clara swung her legs over the side of the bed, her feet meeting the cool floorboards. She needed to see Lily, to hold her, to assure herself that she was safe. The dreams had started a week ago, each one more vivid, more terrifying than the last. They left her shaken and filled with an unshakeable dread, a mother's instinct warning her of danger unseen.

As she padded down the hallway, the house silent save for the creaking of old wood, she wondered if it was merely her own fears manifesting, a response to the world outside and its endless uncertainties. But deep down, she felt it was more than that, a connection she couldn't comprehend, a thread that tied her to something just beyond her grasp.

In his studio, Adrian moved through the familiar ritual of developing film, the repetitive motions calming his racing thoughts. He watched as the images came to life, the chemicals etching the light and shadow onto paper, revealing the world as he saw it. Yet, his mind remained tethered to the girl's eyes, their depth and mystery, and the strange compulsion that had taken root within him.

He had begun to dream of her, though he couldn't recall the details upon waking. It was as if she were a part of him now, embedded in his psyche, a muse and a tormentor all at once. He found himself returning to the park day after day, hoping to glimpse her again, to capture the essence of what had drawn him in so completely.

But she was never there. Only the echoes of her presence lingered, a whisper on the wind, a shadow beneath the trees. The frustration gnawed at him, a constant reminder of the chasm between desire and reality. He spent hours in his studio, surrounded by the detritus of his obsession, sifting through photographs, searching for clues in the grainy images.

Clara stood in the doorway of Lily's room, watching the gentle rise and fall of her daughter's chest. The moonlight cast a soft glow through the window, illuminating the peaceful contours of her face. It was moments like these that she cherished, the stillness and serenity, the assurance that all was well.

Yet, the dreams lingered at the edges of her consciousness, a persistent reminder that peace was fleeting, that shadows lurked just beyond the periphery. She wondered if she should tell someone, confide in a friend, seek advice from those who might understand. But the thought of speaking it aloud made it all too real, and so she remained silent, her fears her own to bear.

As the days passed, Adrian's obsession deepened, a tangled web from which he could not extricate himself. He spent long hours in the archives, poring over old photographs, searching for any trace of the girl, any hint that might explain the hold she had over him. It was during one of these late-night searches that he stumbled upon something that made his blood run cold.

The photograph was old, sepia-toned and faded, yet unmistakable in its detail. There she was, the same girl, the same eyes, captured in a moment frozen in time. But this photograph was decades old, far older than it should have been, and the realization struck him like a physical blow. She had not aged, not in the slightest.

He stared at the image, a chill creeping up his spine. How was it possible? Who was she? The questions raced through his mind, each more frantic than the last. It was as if the world had tilted on its axis, the familiar becoming strange and the strange becoming familiar.

The discovery unraveled something within him, the threads of his obsession pulling tight, binding him to her in ways he could not understand. He felt a compulsion to know more, to uncover the truth that lay hidden beneath layers of time and shadow. Yet, with each step closer, he felt the pull of the abyss, the danger that lurked in the unknown.

Clara's nightmares intensified, the shadows growing bolder, more menacing. In her dreams, she saw Lily not as a child but as a timeless figure, her eyes unchanging, her presence eternal. The strangers with cameras circled closer, their whispers filling the air, a language she could not comprehend but felt in the marrow of her bones.

She awoke each morning with the echoes of those whispers haunting her, a chorus of voices urging her to protect, to guard against the unseen threat. She took to watching Lily more closely, her gaze lingering on her daughter's face, searching for signs, for answers that eluded her waking mind.

It was on one of these mornings, her resolve steeled by the weight of her dreams, that Clara decided to act. She would not wait for the shadows to close in, for the nightmares to become reality. She would seek out those who might understand, who might help unravel the mystery that bound her daughter to forces unknown.

Adrian, too, felt the urgency, the need to confront the truth that had ensnared him. He returned to the park, the place where it had all begun, hoping for answers, for clarity. The fog lay thick over the town, the world hushed and waiting, as if the very air held its breath.

As he wandered the familiar paths, his mind a whirlwind of questions and half-formed theories, he caught sight of her—a flash of color in the gray, a figure standing by the fountain. It was her, the girl from his photographs, unchanged, ethereal in the mist.

His heart raced, a mixture of fear and excitement, as he approached. She turned to face him, her eyes meeting his, and in that moment, he understood. The connection between them, the pull that had drawn him in, was not a product of his imagination. It was real, tangible, a thread that bound them across time and space.

Before he could speak, before he could reach out, a voice cut through the fog, sharp and clear.

"Lily!"

The girl's head turned, her gaze shifting from Adrian to the woman who had called her name. Clara stood at the edge of the park, her heart pounding, her fears realized. She had seen the man before, in her dreams, his camera an extension of his soul, capturing her daughter in ways she could not fathom.

Adrian stepped back, confusion warring with understanding, as the pieces fell into place. The mother, the child, the nightmares and photographs—a tapestry woven with threads of light and shadow, reality and dream.

Clara approached, her expression a mix of protectiveness and curiosity. She had seen the recognition in Adrian's eyes, the understanding that mirrored her own. They stood in silence, the fog swirling around them, the weight of the moment pressing down.

"I need to know," Clara said finally, her voice steady despite the tremor in her heart. "Why her? Why now?"

Adrian met her gaze, the truth on the tip of his tongue, the connection between them undeniable. "I don't know," he admitted, the words raw and honest. "But I think we're meant to find out together."

In that instant, the fog seemed to lift, the world sharpening into focus. They were no longer strangers bound by coincidence but allies in a shared quest, driven by the same need to protect, to understand.

Together, they turned to Lily, the girl who had brought them together, her eyes holding the secrets of a thousand lifetimes. In her gaze, they saw the past and the future, the promise of answers yet to be discovered.

As they walked away from the park, the fog closing in behind them, Adrian and Clara knew their journey was only just beginning. They were bound by the mysteries of the girl with haunting eyes, by the dreams that had led them to this moment.

And as they stepped into the unknown, they felt the pull of the light, the promise of understanding, guiding them forward into a future where shadows and reality intertwined.

The girl with the purple eyes did not like having her picture taken. She scowled into the camera with alarming intensity.

“Smile,” the photographer said, flashing his own toothy grin.

Her face remained unchanged. No one had asked how she felt being cornered by a stranger, or if she wanted to smile, and scowling was her only means of protest.

The girl with the purple eyes didn’t actually have purple eyes—that’s just how they looked to her classmates. Really they were deep-blue. The purple came from them being sunken, dark underneath, like a smudged plum or bruises: the combination of inherited memory—generations and generations of purple-eyed women—and many sleepless nights spent coughing, small lungs gasping for air.

She got her lungs from her father, who had suffered from asthma as well. Growing up, he was thin, probably from the lack of oxygen, breathing in just enough to survive and nothing more. Not enough to thrive or grow or run the way that most boys do, and so he remained small and devoted himself to studying biology and later, medicine. He was different from the other men in his family, and perhaps it was his smallness that made him kind.

The purple-eyed women on her mother’s side began generations ago. Years of stored fears, doubts, holding of breath so that Dad doesn’t hear you under the bed; the acceptance that even if he doesn’t hear you, he knows exactly where you are; the truth that there is no escape. Small girls’ bodies covered in fingerprints, dealt with harshly, like overworked clay.

It’s the lack of air that makes for purple eyes, whether it be from fear, asthma, dreams of drowning, or the inherited memory of what’s mine is theirs, especially if what’s mine is feminine and soft—the remembering through mothers and mothers and mothers.
