Wes’s standard of success had changed since his art school days. Back then he spent hours shooting smoke clouds on film, or nude men in black and white. Back then success meant he had been invited onto a shoot with some obscure creative vision or had scored a free drink at a bar, sent over by someone mysterious, attractive, older. He never could have guessed that elementary-class photos would end up paying his bills, or that he would learn how to make four-year-olds smile with his exaggerated facial expressions, almost without fail.

Damn.

She was enveloped in dense, still darkness. She felt a small rustle and realized she was in Ella’s room, kneeling beside her bed. She felt her own face, wet with tears; felt her arms and shoulders, her chest, making sure she was in her adult body again.

Then she felt Ella’s arm, gently; her shoulders, her head. She was warm, small and whole, still in her Cinderella nightgown, breathing deeply. Her eyes fluttered open.

“Mom, did you have a bad dream?” Ella asked, her voice full of sleep. She stroked her mom’s head gently, the way someone might pet a wild animal or baby bird.

“Ella, I did. I had a really bad dream.”

“Do you want to get in? To help you sleep?” Ella lifted her comforter a bit, showing the wide expanse of unoccupied twin bed to her left.

“For a little bit. Just until Dad gets home.” Nicole answered, climbing into bed.
story_a:
The first time I saw her eyes, I was crouched behind the lens of my Leica, adjusting the focus to capture the delicate interplay of light and shadow in the crowded marketplace. It was late afternoon, and the sun cast a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors of the vendor stalls and the faces of the people drifting through the narrow aisles. I was just a visitor, passing through this small town on my way to nowhere in particular, drawn by the promise of capturing the essence of everyday life in my photographs.

Then I saw her. She stood apart from the bustling crowd, a still figure in a sea of movement. Her dark hair framed a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, and her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazed directly into the lens as if she could see through it, into me. They were eyes that spoke of wisdom and sorrow far beyond her years, and I knew in that moment that I had to capture them.

I clicked the shutter once, twice, three times, unable to tear myself away from the intensity of her gaze. It was only when a woman, presumably her mother, hurried over and took her by the hand that I lowered my camera. The woman glanced at me briefly, her expression one of guarded suspicion, before leading the girl away. But those eyes stayed with me, burned into my memory and, more importantly, onto my film.

Back in my small rented room, I developed the photos in the makeshift darkroom I had set up in the bathroom. The image of the girl emerged slowly, the chemicals revealing the stark contrast of her pale face against the dark backdrop of the market. Her eyes, even in black and white, seemed to hold a depth that was almost supernatural. I found myself staring at the photograph long after it had dried, tracing the lines of her face with my finger, lost in the mystery of who she was and what her eyes were trying to tell me.

Days turned into weeks, and I couldn't shake the image of the girl from my mind. I returned to the marketplace every day, hoping to see her again, but she was never there. I asked around, describing her to the vendors and the regulars, but no one seemed to know who she was. It was as if she had appeared out of nowhere, a ghost haunting my thoughts and my art.

My obsession with the girl began to consume me. I spent hours each night developing and re-developing the same photograph, trying to tease out more details, to understand the story behind those eyes. I started to dream about her, vivid and unsettling dreams where she would appear in different places—standing in the corner of my room, sitting at the edge of my bed, always watching me with that unblinking gaze.

One night, as I was poring over the photograph yet again, a knock on the door startled me. I opened it to find the girl's mother standing there, her face pale and drawn, her eyes filled with a mixture of fear and desperation.

"Please," she said, her voice trembling. "You have to stop."

"Stop what?" I asked, genuinely confused.

"Taking pictures of my daughter," she replied. "You've been following us, haven't you?"

"No, I—" I began, but she cut me off.

"I can feel it," she said, her voice rising. "Every night, I see her in my dreams, watched by strangers, dissected by their eyes and their cameras. It's driving me mad. You have to stop."

Her words stunned me into silence. I had no idea that my obsession had been affecting her so deeply, that she had been experiencing the same nightmares that plagued me. I wanted to explain, to apologize, but the intensity of her emotion left me speechless.

"Please," she repeated, tears welling up in her eyes. "Let us be."

She turned and walked away before I could respond, leaving me standing in the doorway, the weight of her words heavy on my shoulders. I closed the door and returned to my darkroom, staring at the photograph of the girl one last time before tucking it away in a drawer.

I didn't go back to the marketplace after that. I packed my things and moved on, hoping to leave the haunting eyes and the nightmares behind. But even now, years later, I can still see her face in my mind, those eyes staring out at me from the depths of my memory, a reminder of the unintended consequences of my obsession.

In the years that followed, I traveled far and wide, capturing images of people and places, each photograph a testament to the world as I saw it. But no matter how many faces I photographed, none ever held the same power, the same haunting beauty, as the eyes of that young girl in the marketplace.

As time passed, I found myself returning to that small town, drawn by an inexplicable need to confront the past. The marketplace was still there, much the same as I remembered it, the same vendors selling their wares, the same vibrant energy filling the air. But the girl and her mother were nowhere to be found.

I wandered through the narrow aisles, my camera hanging heavy around my neck, feeling a strange sense of loss and longing. I had hoped that coming back here would bring some sort of closure, but instead, it only deepened the mystery. I felt like a ghost, drifting through a place that no longer held any answers.

It was late afternoon when I stumbled upon a small photography shop tucked away in a quiet corner of the marketplace. Curious, I stepped inside, the bell above the door tinkling softly. The shop was filled with old cameras and photographs, a treasure trove of memories captured on film.

As I browsed the shelves, my eyes were drawn to a photograph hanging on the wall. It was a portrait of a young girl, her dark hair framing a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazing directly into the camera. My heart skipped a beat as I realized it was the same girl I had photographed all those years ago.

I turned to the shopkeeper, an elderly man with a kind smile and a twinkle in his eye.

"Who is she?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

The shopkeeper looked at the photograph and then back at me, his smile fading.

"She was my granddaughter," he said softly. "She passed away many years ago."

I felt a lump form in my throat as I processed his words. The girl, the haunting eyes, the nightmares—it all made sense now. She had been trying to tell me something, to reach out from beyond the grave, and I had been too blind to see it.

"I'm sorry," I said, my voice choked with emotion. "I didn't know."

The shopkeeper nodded, his eyes filled with a sadness that mirrored my own.

"She was special," he said. "Her eyes saw things that others couldn't. She had a gift, but it also brought her great pain."

I felt a deep sense of guilt wash over me, realizing that my obsession with her had only added to that pain. I wanted to make amends, to find some way to honor her memory, but I didn't know how.

"May I buy the photograph?" I asked, hoping that having it would bring some measure of closure.

The shopkeeper shook his head. "It's not for sale," he said gently. "But you can have it. She would have wanted you to have it."

I took the photograph from the wall, feeling its weight in my hands. It was more than just a picture; it was a connection to a past I could never fully understand, a reminder of the consequences of my actions and the haunting beauty of those eyes.

As I left the shop, I felt a strange sense of peace settle over me. The girl's eyes would always be with me, a silent witness to my journey and a testament to the power of a single moment captured on film. And in that moment, I knew that my obsession had not been in vain. It had led me to a deeper understanding of myself and the world around me, and for that, I was grateful.

I walked through the marketplace one last time, the photograph clutched tightly in my hand. The sun was setting, casting a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors and the shadows. I raised my camera and took one final picture, capturing the essence of the place that had changed my life forever. And as I did, I felt the weight of the past lift from my shoulders, replaced by a sense of hope and possibility.

In the end, it was not the photograph of the girl that haunted me, but the lesson she had taught me: that every image, every moment, holds a story waiting to be discovered, and that sometimes, the most powerful stories are the ones that we least expect.
story_b:
In the dim light of his studio, where shadows danced among the equipment and the scent of developing chemicals lingered like a ghost, the photographer stared at the image on his screen. The girl's eyes—two vast pools of midnight—held him captive, their depths whispering secrets and stories that he could not fully grasp. Each click of the shutter had felt like a heartbeat, a pulse that connected him to something beyond the lens, yet as elusive as the flickering light that played over her face.

He had met her by chance at a local fair, where the air was thick with laughter and the sweet aroma of cotton candy. She had been seated on a carousel horse, her eyes scanning the crowd with a curious, searching gaze that seemed to pierce through the noise. Drawn inexplicably to those eyes, he had asked her mother if he could take a few pictures. The mother, a woman with a weary smile and lavender-scented hair, had hesitated before nodding her consent.

Now, in the quiet solitude of his studio, he found himself returning to that moment, reliving it with an intensity that bordered on obsession. He studied the girl's image, tracing every contour, every shadow, as if trying to unlock some hidden truth within the depths of her stare. Her eyes were windows to a world he could never enter, yet couldn't look away from.

Across town, the girl's mother lay in bed, surrounded by the comforting scents of lavender and chamomile, yet unable to escape the grip of her nightmares. Every night, the dreams came, uninvited and relentless, leaving her breathless and afraid. In the dark theater of her mind, she saw her daughter ensnared by shadows that crept like silent predators, wrapping around her image with an insidious intent. Strangers watched and dissected her child with eyes that were as cold and unfeeling as the lens of a camera.

She awoke in a cold sweat, heart pounding with a frantic rhythm that matched the fear coursing through her veins. Her daughter's room was just down the hall, a sanctuary filled with protective symbols—dreamcatchers, soft toys, and the gentle glow of a nightlight that warded off the darkness. Yet the nightmares seeped into her waking hours, casting a pall over her interactions with her daughter, who remained blissfully unaware of the specters that haunted her mother.

The photographer, meanwhile, found himself consumed by the girl's eyes, their haunting beauty a siren call that echoed in his thoughts. He began to see her eyes everywhere, in the reflections of storefront windows, in the shimmering surface of his morning coffee, in the depths of his own dreams where they loomed larger than life. His fascination grew into a relentless tide, washing over his days and nights, pulling him further into a world he could not comprehend.

He tried to capture the essence of those eyes in his work, but each attempt left him feeling empty, as if the soul of the image had slipped through his fingers. He wanted to call the mother, to ask for another session, another chance to explore the mystery that had ensnared him. Yet something held him back—a whisper of guilt that warned him of crossing a line he could not see but sensed was there.

The mother's nightmares intensified, the images more vivid, more terrifying. Her daughter's laughter, once a balm to her soul, now carried an edge of fear, the echoes of her dreams bleeding into reality. She watched her child with a growing sense of unease, as if expecting the shadows to reach out and claim her. The protective symbols in her home offered little comfort against the relentless march of her fears.

"All right," she said at last, her voice barely above a whisper. "But only if I'm there with her."

Yet as he prepared for the session, a sliver of unease crept into his thoughts, a feeling that perhaps he was venturing too close to something sacred, something he had no right to claim.

The day of the session arrived, and the mother watched as the photographer set up his equipment with a meticulous care that bordered on reverence. Her daughter sat patiently, her eyes wide with curiosity, oblivious to the tension that hung in the air. As the photographer began to click away, the mother observed him closely, noting the intensity with which he studied her child, the way his gaze lingered on those haunting eyes.

The photographer was lost in the moment, absorbed by the interplay of light and shadow, the way the girl's eyes seemed to draw him into a world he could never fully understand. Yet with each shot, he felt a growing sense of frustration, as if the truth he sought remained just beyond his grasp.

The mother, too, felt the weight of the session, her nightmares hovering at the edges of her consciousness. She watched her daughter's image flash across the screen, her heart a tumult of love and fear, the shadows of her dreams whispering their insidious warnings. Yet as the session drew to a close, she saw something in the photographer's eyes—a flicker of understanding, a glimpse of the struggle within him.

As they packed up, the photographer hesitated, his mind a whirlwind of conflicting emotions. He wanted to thank the mother, to express his gratitude for allowing him another glimpse into the world behind her daughter's eyes. Yet he also felt the weight of his obsession, the knowledge that he had crossed a line that perhaps should have remained intact.

"Thank you," he said at last, his voice a quiet echo in the room. "Her eyes... they're extraordinary."

The mother nodded, her own emotions a tangled web of relief and lingering unease. "They are," she agreed, her voice soft. "But they're just a part of her."

He nodded, understanding more than he had before. The girl's eyes were indeed extraordinary, but they were not the whole of her. They were windows to a world that was both captivating and elusive, a world he could admire but never fully possess.

As they parted ways, the photographer felt a sense of closure, a release from the grip of his obsession. He had seen the depths of those haunting eyes, had tried to capture their essence, but in the end, he realized that some mysteries were not meant to be unraveled. They were to be cherished, admired from a distance, like the beauty of a star-streaked sky or the fleeting glow of a sunset.

For the mother, the session marked a turning point in her battle with the nightmares. She saw her daughter's image not as a harbinger of fear, but as a beacon of strength and innocence. The shadows still lurked at the edges of her dreams, but she faced them with renewed resolve, knowing that her love was the strongest shield against the darkness.

In the quiet of their separate worlds, both the photographer and the mother found a measure of peace. Their paths had crossed in a moment of shared wonder, their lives briefly intertwined by the haunting beauty of a child's eyes. And though they would never meet again, the memory of that shared moment lingered, a testament to the power of connection and the mysteries that bind us all.

prompt: A photographer becomes obsessed with the haunting eyes of a young girl he captures on film, unaware that her mother is plagued by vivid nightmares of her daughter being watched, dissected, and photographed by strangers.
ground_truth:
The girl with the purple eyes did not like having her picture taken. She scowled into the camera with alarming intensity.

“Smile,” the photographer said, flashing his own toothy grin.

Her face remained unchanged. No one had asked how she felt being cornered by a stranger, or if she wanted to smile, and scowling was her only means of protest.

The girl with the purple eyes didn’t actually have purple eyes—that’s just how they looked to her classmates. Really they were deep-blue. The purple came from them being sunken, dark underneath, like a smudged plum or bruises: the combination of inherited memory—generations and generations of purple-eyed women—and many sleepless nights spent coughing, small lungs gasping for air.

She got her lungs from her father, who had suffered from asthma as well. Growing up, he was thin, probably from the lack of oxygen, breathing in just enough to survive and nothing more. Not enough to thrive or grow or run the way that most boys do, and so he remained small and devoted himself to studying biology and later, medicine. He was different from the other men in his family, and perhaps it was his smallness that made him kind.

The purple-eyed women on her mother’s side began generations ago. Years of stored fears, doubts, holding of breath so that Dad doesn’t hear you under the bed; the acceptance that even if he doesn’t hear you, he knows exactly where you are; the truth that there is no escape. Small girls’ bodies covered in fingerprints, dealt with harshly, like overworked clay.

It’s the lack of air that makes for purple eyes, whether it be from fear, asthma, dreams of drowning, or the inherited memory of what’s mine is theirs, especially if what’s mine is feminine and soft—the remembering through mothers and mothers and mothers.

After taking her photo, the toothy man, Wes, gave her a nod. While he wished he could’ve coaxed a smile out of this last one, it had been a pretty successful day. Two hours of wrangling a pre-K class into solo photos outside on the playground without a single tantrum or tear shed was success in his book.

Wes’s standard of success had changed since his art school days. Back then he spent hours shooting smoke clouds on film, or nude men in black and white. Back then success meant he had been invited onto a shoot with some obscure creative vision or had scored a free drink at a bar, sent over by someone mysterious, attractive, older. He never could have guessed that elementary-class photos would end up paying his bills, or that he would learn how to make four-year-olds smile with his exaggerated facial expressions, almost without fail.

When he got home Wes popped a bag of ready-to-steam frozen edamame into the microwave and stared at the photo of that girl, the one with eyes so deep he felt they might fall right into her head.

Damn.

She was only four or five, with bangs that cut straight across her forehead, her hair pulled back at the nape of her neck into a loose ponytail. She wore a smocked blue cotton dress that popped against her olive skin. It was an eerie photo, and this was one of those rare moments when he looked at his work and remembered what it felt like to be an artist. Suddenly, he was glad she hadn’t smiled. This made for a much better photo. Maybe not something her parents would want to hang on the fridge, but still.


Nicole pulled up thirty minutes late, screeching to a halt in front of the school. Thirty minutes late meant she would have to retrieve Ella from the office.

“We have a three-strike system, okay?” said Ms. Smith, the school’s head of administration. She was a petite lady with a southern accent, always wearing a full face of makeup, always in heels. She was someone whom Nicole would have avoided at first glance, but two months into the school year Ms. Smith had proven to be kind, warm-hearted, and welcoming while Ella and her mom learned what it meant to attend St. Ignatius Day School.

“Don’t fret about it today. I know how hard it can be with traffic and all. It’s just a formality,” she said, handing Ella’s mom a hot-pink “tardy slip.”

Despite Ms. Smith’s reassurance, the hot-pink slip certainly felt like more than just a formality. As she strode down the hall to the office, every teacher she passed stared her down, giving her a disdainful once-over. She folded the piece of paper and shoved it into her purse.

Don’t you care about your child? Are you completely self-absorbed? Don’t you know how traumatizing it is to be forgotten? Think of how this could impact her future.

She added her own harsh words to their disapproving glances.

Quite honestly, she had forgotten Ella. Well, not forgotten entirely—she had lost track of time. She had been drifting in and out of sleep, and suddenly it was 2:55, leaving her just five minutes to make the almost thirty-minute drive to Ella’s school.

She hadn’t taken the time to put on something more “adult,” or even more “mom,” and now she walked briskly through the hallway in Ugg slippers and mismatched pajamas.

On the way home Ella and her mom stopped for Chick-fil-A, a rare indulgence that they decided they had both earned. Ella got a fried-chicken sandwich and a Sprite. She ate about half her sandwich before tucking the rest away in the pocket of the seat in front of her, saving it for later. She took a pull of Sprite through the straw and nodded the way little kids do when they are exceptionally pleased with their choice in beverage.

Ella caught her mom’s eye in the rearview mirror and scrunched up her face in a smile.

Relief swept through Nicole’s shoulders and chest. She could almost cry.

“Today a man with very white teeth took our pictures without asking,” Ella said.

“I know, hon. I told you about school pictures today. That’s why you wore your dress, remember?”

“I think I forgot,” Ella stated matter-of-factly, taking another swig of Sprite.

“That’s okay, Ella. Hey, on our way home I’m going to run into Walgreens, okay? You can stay in the car and finish your Sprite.”

Ella nodded.


Wes grabbed his gym bag from the bench by the door and threw it over his shoulder, digging around in his jacket pocket for his car keys. At thirty-three, he had promised himself that he would never fall victim to that soft, midthirties dad-bod that so many of his friends had grown into, so he worked out often and ate “clean.” Sure, dad-bods were fine for them—most of them settling into complacent, accepting relationships—but he could do better.

On his way to the gym he stopped by the Walgreens to pick up some Advil, Irish Springs body wash, and a Gatorade Zero. Out of habit he waved at the TV monitor that greeted him, and the tiny mirror image version of him on the monitor waved back.

A woman walked in just as he finished waving, and Wes caught a glimpse of her in the monitor. He was transported. Her eyes were sad, sunken, dark, purple underneath, almost like someone had taken a fist to each of them. It was the second time that day Wes had seen eyes like those. His eyes followed her to the prescription counter, until the rotating display of reading glasses blocked her from view.

That evening Wes fell asleep on the couch while watching Spencer, his favorite film about Princess Diana. His dreams began with the haunted face of Princess Di as she appeared in the film, played by Kristen Stewart, withering away under the watchful eye of the royal family. Suddenly she was joined by the purple-eyed girl and the purple-eyed woman he had seen earlier that day. The three of them followed him everywhere he went—the gym, the grocery store, the car wash—but in a strange turn of events, he realized that it was he who was following them. He caught their reflections in windows, TV screens, puddles in the street. He stalked them with his camera, like a member of the paparazzi, desperate to get the right angle, the perfect photo. They did not say anything to him or acknowledge that he was there. He followed them all the way to their house in the English countryside, and then he woke up.


Ella’s dad worked late that night, so Ella and her mom agreed to watch a few episodes of Little Bear while Ella had a breathing treatment. The mask fit over her mouth and nose with a blue elastic strap that went behind her head, like the kind they show you on an airplane “in case of a loss of cabin pressure.” By now Ella was used to the sounds and smells of albuterol being pumped into her lungs and she relaxed into her beanbag chair, watching while Little Bear scooped the moon up into his bucket of water. One hour later, Ella was showered and tucked into bed wearing her polyester blue Cinderella nightgown.

“Goodnight, Ella. Sweet dreams,” her mom said, pulling her door almost to a close.

Then Nicole crawled into her own bed, allowing her feet to stretch as far as they could down into the cool cotton sheets, allowing herself to spread starfish for a moment before turning over onto her left side into a small fetal position.

It would be a late night for Michael, which meant a less than ideal night’s sleep for her. She would be on edge until he got home. She tried waiting up and opened her copy of The House of the Spirits, a book she had reread more times than she could count. Somehow she found it comforting. Something about the stored-up generations of motherhood, the trauma manifested in physical bodies, the brokenness, but also the slow growth and healing that rolled through the Trueba and del Valle families. It made her feel hopeful. She drifted in and out of sleep. Eventually, she slipped into deep sleep, the kind filled with rhythmic breathing and vivid dreams.

She dreamed that she was wandering the hallways of a big creaky house with heavy curtains and doors. She didn’t recognize the house but seemed to know exactly where to go. She was small again and wore a white nightgown smattered with blue and pink flowers. She was looking for something.

She found her way to the kitchen and paused outside the closed door. There were voices on the other side and she could see the lights on, glowing underneath. They were cold, blue, like hospital lights, or the kind associated with an alien abduction—not like the lights of the kitchen she knew. The voices she heard sounded sterile. She didn’t want to open the door because she didn’t want anyone to see her, so she peeked through the keyhole and let out a silent scream.

Splayed out on the kitchen table was Nicole’s Ella, though in this strange world she and Ella both looked about five—not possibly mother and daughter. Ella was spread wide like a butchered animal, two men bent over her little body—men rummaging around in her abdomen, poking and prodding with long metal prongs, wringing out her insides like wet paper towels, slicing through her soft belly and cracking open her chest cavity. They whispered and laughed. They seemed to be searching for something inside her, like pearl divers slicing open oyster shells, unbothered by oyster flesh and juice.

Ella’s mom could hear every snap and squelch as the men made themselves familiar with Ella’s insides, as if the awful sounds were being broadcast over a loud speaker. Then one of the men pulled out a camera with a big flashbulb on top and started snapping pictures of Ella’s body from all different angles, contorted, bloodied, splayed open, her eyes empty and deep. Every flash lit the room like a burst of lightning, and the snap of the lens made Ella’s mom feel sick—the snap, flash, snap, flash over and over again, like a strobe light.

This was more than Nicole could bear, and she let out another scream, though this one was not silent. It was loud, desperate to be heard.

Suddenly she was awake, catching the end of her own scream, which had followed her from nightmare into consciousness. For a moment she didn’t know where she was. She was enveloped in dense, still darkness. She felt a small rustle and realized she was in Ella’s room, kneeling beside her bed. She felt her own face, wet with tears; felt her arms and shoulders, her chest, making sure she was in her adult body again.

Then she felt Ella’s arm, gently; her shoulders, her head. She was warm, small and whole, still in her Cinderella nightgown, breathing deeply. Her eyes fluttered open.

“Mom, did you have a bad dream?” Ella asked, her voice full of sleep. She stroked her mom’s head gently, the way someone might pet a wild animal or baby bird.

“Ella, I did. I had a really bad dream.”

“Do you want to get in? To help you sleep?” Ella lifted her comforter a bit, showing the wide expanse of unoccupied twin bed to her left.

“For a little bit. Just until Dad gets home.” Nicole answered, climbing into bed.

She turned and walked away before I could respond, leaving me standing in the doorway, the weight of her words heavy on my shoulders. I closed the door and returned to my darkroom, staring at the photograph of the girl one last time before tucking it away in a drawer.

I didn't go back to the marketplace after that. I packed my things and moved on, hoping to leave the haunting eyes and the nightmares behind. But even now, years later, I can still see her face in my mind, those eyes staring out at me from the depths of my memory, a reminder of the unintended consequences of my obsession.

In the years that followed, I traveled far and wide, capturing images of people and places, each photograph a testament to the world as I saw it. But no matter how many faces I photographed, none ever held the same power, the same haunting beauty, as the eyes of that young girl in the marketplace.

As time passed, I found myself returning to that small town, drawn by an inexplicable need to confront the past. The marketplace was still there, much the same as I remembered it, the same vendors selling their wares, the same vibrant energy filling the air. But the girl and her mother were nowhere to be found.

I wandered through the narrow aisles, my camera hanging heavy around my neck, feeling a strange sense of loss and longing. I had hoped that coming back here would bring some sort of closure, but instead, it only deepened the mystery. I felt like a ghost, drifting through a place that no longer held any answers.

It was late afternoon when I stumbled upon a small photography shop tucked away in a quiet corner of the marketplace. Curious, I stepped inside, the bell above the door tinkling softly. The shop was filled with old cameras and photographs, a treasure trove of memories captured on film.

It was a portrait of a young girl, her dark hair framing a face that seemed both ageless and ancient, her eyes—those haunting, deep-set eyes—gazing directly into the camera. My heart skipped a beat as I realized it was the same girl I had photographed all those years ago.

I turned to the shopkeeper, an elderly man with a kind smile and a twinkle in his eye.

"Who is she?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

The shopkeeper looked at the photograph and then back at me, his smile fading.

"She was my granddaughter," he said softly. "She passed away many years ago."

I felt a lump form in my throat as I processed his words. The girl, the haunting eyes, the nightmares—it all made sense now. She had been trying to tell me something, to reach out from beyond the grave, and I had been too blind to see it.

"I'm sorry," I said, my voice choked with emotion. "I didn't know."

The shopkeeper nodded, his eyes filled with a sadness that mirrored my own.

"She was special," he said. "Her eyes saw things that others couldn't. She had a gift, but it also brought her great pain."

I felt a deep sense of guilt wash over me, realizing that my obsession with her had only added to that pain. I wanted to make amends, to find some way to honor her memory, but I didn't know how.

I walked through the marketplace one last time, the photograph clutched tightly in my hand. The sun was setting, casting a golden hue over the scene, deepening the colors and the shadows. I raised my camera and took one final picture, capturing the essence of the place that had changed my life forever. And as I did, I felt the weight of the past lift from my shoulders, replaced by a sense of hope and possibility.

The photograph lay on the table, a silent testament to an obsession that had begun to consume him. The girl's eyes, captured in a fleeting moment of vulnerability, stared back at him, pools of shadow, deep and unknowable, like the depths of a forgotten well. Each click of the shutter had felt like a step deeper into an abyss of obsession, yet he couldn’t look away.

In the dim light of his cluttered darkroom, the photographer traced the contours of the image, his fingers hovering just above the surface as if afraid to touch it. The room smelled of chemicals and old film, the air thick with the weight of countless images, each vying for attention, yet none as commanding as this. His mind, once a sharp lens focusing solely on the craft, now felt chaotic, spiraling into a fixation that refused to release him.

He remembered the day vividly. The sun had been setting, casting a warm glow over the park where he often found inspiration. He had been drawn to the laughter of children, the innocence that seemed so fleeting and fragile. That’s when he saw her, the young girl, sitting alone on a bench, her gaze distant, lost in thoughts only she could fathom. There was something about her eyes that called to him, a silent plea or perhaps a challenge, daring him to capture the essence of her soul.

“Those eyes,” he murmured to himself, the phrase echoing in the dim room, a mantra that had become both comfort and torment.

His memories drifted to other subjects, other haunting images that had once gripped him. There was the old man with eyes like storm clouds, filled with stories untold. The young couple whose gaze held secrets only they shared. Yet none had left a mark as indelible as the girl with the haunting eyes. It was as if, in capturing her, he had also captured a piece of himself, a fragment of his own soul that he had long forgotten.

Meanwhile, across town, the girl's mother tossed in her sleep, caught in the throes of another vivid nightmare. The room was dimly lit, shadows playing across the walls, as if echoing the turmoil within her mind. In her dreams, she saw her daughter, surrounded by strangers, their eyes cold and analytical, dissecting her with their gaze, stripping away her innocence piece by piece. She reached out, trying to protect her, but her hands passed through as if her daughter were nothing more than a ghost.

Each nightmare was the same, a relentless cycle that left her waking in a cold sweat, her heart pounding in her chest. She would sit up, her breath ragged, the silence of the room pressing in on her like a weight. Her daughter slept peacefully down the hall, unaware of the fears that plagued her mother’s mind, of the dark eyes that watched her even in her dreams.

In the small hours of the morning, she would find herself at her daughter’s door, watching the rise and fall of her chest, assuring herself that she was safe, untouched by the shadows that haunted her sleep. Yet the unease lingered, a persistent whisper that warned of unseen dangers, of eyes that watched from the darkness.

Back in his darkroom, the photographer’s obsession grew. He found himself returning to the photograph, studying every detail, searching for answers to questions he couldn’t fully articulate. Who was she? What stories lay hidden behind those eyes? Each examination only deepened his fascination, driving him to capture more, to seek out other subjects that might offer a glimpse of the same haunting depth.

He began to see her eyes everywhere. In the reflection of a storefront window, in the rearview mirror of his car, in the faces of strangers who passed him on the street. It was as if the world had become a gallery, each image a reminder of the gaze that had ensnared him.

Yet with each new photograph, he felt a growing disquiet, a sense that he was intruding on something sacred, something that wasn’t his to capture. The line between artist and voyeur blurred, leaving him trapped in a labyrinth of his own making, desperate for a way out but unwilling to let go.

The mother, too, found herself caught in a cycle of fear and uncertainty. She watched her daughter with a new intensity, searching for signs that might explain the nightmares, the sense of foreboding that hung over their lives like a dark cloud. She began to notice small changes, the way her daughter’s gaze would linger on strangers, as if recognizing something familiar in their eyes.

One afternoon, as they walked through the park, she caught sight of the photographer, his camera raised, capturing the world in frames. Her heart skipped a beat, an inexplicable dread settling over her. She didn’t know him, had never met him, yet something about his presence felt like an echo of her dreams, a shadow that had crossed from her nightmares into reality.

She tightened her grip on her daughter’s hand, pulling her closer, as if proximity could shield her from the unseen threat. Her daughter glanced up, a question in her eyes, but the mother only smiled, hiding her fear behind a mask of calm.

The photographer, oblivious to her gaze, continued his work, driven by a compulsion he couldn’t name. He was aware of the world around him only as shapes and shadows, subjects to be captured, moments to be preserved. His focus remained on the girl, the mystery of her eyes, the story they seemed to promise.

As the days turned into weeks, the mother’s nightmares intensified, each more vivid than the last. She began to dread the night, the darkness that brought with it visions of her daughter’s innocence being stripped away by unseen eyes. She tried to shake the feeling, to convince herself that they were only dreams, but the fear clung to her, a persistent shadow that refused to fade.

The photographer, too, found himself in a state of unrest. He spent hours in his darkroom, the photograph a constant presence, a reminder of the obsession that had taken hold. He began to question his motives, his right to capture the lives of others, to dissect them with his lens.

“The photograph was a mirror,” he thought, reflecting not just her image but the haunting echoes of his own soul. It was as if, in capturing her, he had also captured a part of himself, a fragment he had long sought but never found.

Yet the answers remained elusive, slipping through his fingers like sand. He was left with only questions, the haunting eyes of the girl his only clue, a puzzle he was desperate to solve.

The mother, in her dimly lit bedroom, found herself haunted by her own reflections. She saw her daughter’s innocence in every shadow, every corner, and feared the day when it might be taken from her. Her dreams, once a source of comfort, had become a battleground, a place where she fought to protect her child from unseen threats, from eyes that watched and waited.

The cycle continued, each caught in their own struggle, their paths intertwined by a photograph that had captured more than just a moment. The photographer, in his darkroom, and the mother, in her bedroom, both haunted by the image, by the eyes that held more than they could ever know.

And so it began again, the photographer reviewing the photograph, the mother waking from another nightmare, both trapped in a dance of shadows and light, of obsession and fear. Each seeking answers, each finding only more questions, the haunting eyes of the girl a constant reminder of the mysteries that lay just beyond their reach.

prompt: When the word "hospice" is first spoken, it feels like the air itself changes, heavy with finality. How do you create light in a space where hope seems to have vanished?
ground_truth:
“Hospice.”

Once the word is uttered aloud, there is a seismic shift. You will feel it.


Like a (very short) thread through the eye of a needle, swiftly in and swiftly out.

The air itself becomes thin, steely.

At the periphery of your vision, an immediate dimming. The penumbra begins to shrink. In time, it will become a tunnel. Ever diminishing. Until the remaining light is small enough to be cupped in two hands. And then it will be extinguished.

For when “hospice” is spoken, the fact is at last acknowledged: There is no hope.

No hope. These words are obscene, unspeakable. To be without hope is to be without a future.

Worse, by acknowledging that you are without a future, you have “given up.”

And so when the word “hospice” is first spoken—carefully, cautiously, by a (female) palliative-care physician—neither of you hears it. Or, if you hear it, you don’t register that you have heard.

A low-grade buzzing in the ears, a ringing, as of a distant alarm, an alarm in a shuttered room. That is all.

For if you don’t hear, perhaps it has not (yet) been uttered.

For if neither of you hears, perhaps it will not (ever) be uttered.

Yet somehow it happens: “hospice” comes to be more frequently spoken as the days pass.

And somehow it happens that your husband, surprising himself, begins to speak of his “final days.” As in, “I think these might be my final days.”

As if shyly. On the phone very early one morning, when he calls, as he has been calling, immediately after the oncologist making rounds in the hospital has examined him.

Crossword Puzzles with a Side of Millennial Socialism


On the phone, so that he is spared seeing your face. And you, his.

A new shyness like the first, initial shyness. Finding some way to say I love you.

For some, an impossible statement—I love you.

But your husband managed it, and you managed it, somehow: I love you.

And now, years later, it is “I think these might be my final days.”

These words you hear over the phone distinctly, irrevocably, yet (you would claim) you have not heard them. No!

But, yes, you’ve heard. Must have heard. For the walls of the room reel giddily around you, blood rushes out of your head, leaving you faint, sinking to your knees like a terrified child, stammering, “What? What are you saying? That’s ridiculous. Don’t say such things! What on earth do you mean—‘final days’?”

Your voice rises wildly. You want to fling the cell phone from you.

For you can’t bear it. You don’t think so. Not knowing, at this time, the vast Sahara that lies ahead with all that you cannot bear, that nonetheless will be borne, and by you.

For always, each step of the way, you resist.

It is a steep uphill. It is natural to resist. Or, if you accept the steep climb, console yourself with the thought that it is only temporary. The plateau, the flatland to which you’ve been accustomed, awaits you, both of you. You will return there. Soon.

Until a day, an hour—always there is a day, an hour—when you began to speak of hospice yourself.

At first, you, too, are shy, faltering. Your throat feels lacerated as if by metal filings.

Gradually, you learn to utter the two syllables clearly, bravely—hos-pice.

Soon after that, you begin to say these distinct, deliberate words: “our hospice.”

Soon, you draw up your vows. Quaintly state to yourself, as if to God, a formal decree.

It is my hope: I will make of our hospice a honeymoon.

My vow is to make my husband as comfortable as humanly possible.

To make him happy. To make us both happy.

To fulfill whatever he wishes that is within the range of possibility.

First: a new setting for him. NOT the Cancer Center. Our hospice will be in our home, which he loves.

The atrium flooded with morning light.

The foreshortened horizon—for the house is surrounded by trees.

The flotillas of sculpted clouds.

My husband can lie on a sofa, staring at the tree line and at the sky. Comfortable on the sofa with pillows behind him and feet (in warm socks) elevated.

Or, more likely, he can lie on a (rented) hospital bed, positioned in such a way that he can easily gaze out the window. And I can lie beside him, as I have done in the hospital.

Holding hands. Of course, we will hold hands. His hands are still warm—strong. His fingers, when squeezed, never fail to squeeze in return.

As his lips, when kissed, never fail to kiss in return.

I will sleep beside my husband holding him in my arms, not strong arms, in fact, rather weak arms, which nonetheless can be made to behave as if they were strong.

I will scatter seed on the redwood deck outside the window. Not ordinary seed but the more expensive “wild bird seed” my husband purchases.

Thrilling to watch the birds. Taking the time, undistracted, really watching, for once . . .

And my husband loves music! I will bathe him in the most beautiful music through his waking hours. So long as it is not uncomfortable for him, I will lie on the bed beside him, holding him, listening with him to Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy,” Rachmaninoff’s “Vespers.”


Falling asleep with him. Even during the day. Even with wan sunshine slanting through the window onto our faces. Head on the pillow beside his head.

From the bookcases in the house, I will select art books, his favorite artists, books from his photography shelves—Bruce Davidson, Edward Weston, Diane Arbus, Eliot Porter. I will turn the pages slowly, marvel with him.

Old albums, family photographs dating back to the early nineteen-hundreds. His family, great-grandparents who emigrated from the Pale. In which he has only recently shown an interest.

His favorite foods. . . . Well, I will try!

When he is at home, possibly his appetite will return. When I am the one to prepare his food, his appetite will return, I am sure.

Of course, family will come to visit. Adult children, grandchildren. Relatives, friends. Colleagues from the university. Neighbors. Old friends from grammar school he hasn’t seen in fifty years. Some surprises for him—I will negotiate with the imagination of a theatre director.

Not merely hospice but our hospice. Not sad but joyous, a honeymoon.

We will be happy there, in our own home. Both of us.

For both of us, the “final days” will be a honeymoon. I vow.

In fact, nothing remotely like this will happen. How could you have imagined it would!

Hospice, yes. Honeymoon, no.
story_a:
When the word "hospice" is first spoken, it feels like the air itself changes, heavy with finality. The syllables linger in the room, almost visible, as if they have weight and shape, settling over the furniture, the bed, and the person lying in it. Clara hears it and feels an almost imperceptible shift in the universe, a closing door. It’s her mother, Marjorie, who the doctor is addressing, but the word reverberates through Clara’s own heart, a dull thud of inevitability.

Marjorie stares at the doctor with a mix of resignation and defiance, her once-vibrant green eyes now clouded by the long battle with illness. She nods slowly, her lips pressed into a thin line, and then looks away, out the window where a soft autumn rain begins to fall. Clara watches her mother’s profile, the sharp lines softened by the afternoon light, and feels a pang of something she cannot name.

They return home, the word "hospice" now a silent companion that follows them through the days. Clara finds herself moving through the motions of care with an urgency that surprises her. She arranges visits from the nurses, fills out forms, and talks in hushed tones with her mother’s friends, who come bearing casseroles and quiet condolences.

In the evenings, after the house has settled into its own kind of weary quiet, Clara sits by her mother’s bedside, reading aloud from old favorites—books they had shared during long summer afternoons when she was a child. Marjorie listens with her eyes closed, a faint smile playing at the corners of her mouth, her breath shallow but steady. It is in these moments that Clara feels the weight of loss most acutely, the slow erosion of time slipping through their fingers.

One evening, as the fire in the hearth crackles and the shadows lengthen, Marjorie opens her eyes and reaches for Clara’s hand. Her touch is light, almost ethereal, and Clara feels a sudden rush of tears she struggles to hold back.

“Clara,” Marjorie says softly, her voice barely a whisper. “Do you remember the garden?”

Clara nods, unable to speak. The garden had been Marjorie’s sanctuary, a riot of color and life where she had spent countless hours tending to roses, tulips, and wildflowers. It had been Clara’s playground, a place of wonder and discovery, where she had learned the names of plants and the rhythms of nature.

“I want to see it,” Marjorie says, her eyes shining with a faint glimmer of the old spark. “One last time.”

Clara hesitates, the practical part of her mind already listing the reasons why it might be impossible. But then she sees the determination in her mother’s gaze, the unspoken plea, and she nods.

The next morning, Clara arranges for a wheelchair and blankets, wrapping Marjorie in layers to keep the chill at bay. She pushes her mother through the narrow hallway and out into the garden, where the late autumn sun bathes the world in a golden glow. The air is crisp, filled with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves, and Clara feels a strange sense of peace settle over her.

Marjorie breathes in deeply, her eyes scanning the familiar landscape. The garden is past its prime, the flowers wilted and the branches bare, but there is a beauty in the decay, a quiet dignity in the way the world prepares for winter.

Clara wheels her mother to the old wooden bench under the maple tree, its leaves a brilliant tapestry of reds and golds. She sits beside her, their hands still entwined, and they watch the world together, the silence between them filled with unspoken memories.

For a while, they sit in companionable silence, the only sounds the rustling of leaves and the distant chirping of birds. Clara feels a warmth spread through her, a sense of connection that transcends words. It is as if the garden itself is holding them, cradling them in its embrace, offering a kind of solace that she hadn’t realized she needed.

Marjorie turns to her, her eyes filled with a mixture of gratitude and sadness. “Thank you, Clara,” she says, her voice trembling. “For everything.”

Clara squeezes her mother’s hand, her own heart aching with the weight of all the things she cannot say. She looks around the garden, taking in the details—the way the sunlight filters through the leaves, the intricate patterns of the spider webs glistening with dew, the gentle sway of the grass in the breeze. It is a moment of clarity, a reminder that even in the face of loss, there is beauty and light.

In the days that follow, Clara finds herself drawn to the garden more and more. She spends hours there, tending to the plants, raking leaves, and preparing the soil for the winter. It becomes a ritual, a way to connect with her mother’s spirit, to feel her presence in the place she had loved so deeply.

Marjorie’s decline is gradual but inevitable, and Clara feels the weight of each passing day. She continues to read to her mother, to sit by her side, and to hold her hand through the long nights. The word "hospice" no longer feels like a sentence but a gentle guide, leading them through the final chapter with grace.

One crisp morning, as the first frost dusts the garden in a delicate shimmer, Marjorie slips away. Clara is by her side, her hand still entwined with her mother’s, and she feels a profound stillness settle over her. It is a moment of both grief and release, a quiet ending to a life well-lived.

In the weeks that follow, Clara finds herself returning to the garden, drawn to its quiet resilience. She plants new seeds, tending to them with care, and watches as they begin to sprout, tiny green shoots pushing through the cold earth. It is a reminder of the cycles of life, of the way hope can be found even in the darkest of times.

And so, in the space where hope had seemed to vanish, Clara discovers a new kind of light—a gentle, enduring presence that carries her forward, one day at a time. The garden becomes her sanctuary, a place of healing and remembrance, where the memory of her mother lives on in the whisper of the wind and the bloom of every flower.
story_b:
The morning rounds at Saint Miriam’s Hospice began as they always did, with Nurse Emily weaving through the corridors, her steps soft against the linoleum, her voice a gentle murmur in the quietude. The patients awaited her arrival, some with expectant eyes, others with resignation. The word “hospice” was a whisper in the air, its presence undeniable, like a shadow that lingered even in the brightest rooms.

“How are you feeling today?” Emily asked as she entered each room, the question a thread connecting her to those she cared for. It was a ritual, almost sacred in its repetition. For Gerald, the elderly man with thinning hair and eyes that once sparkled with mischief, the response was always the same: “I’m just waiting.” His voice carried the weight of his years, each word heavy with the life he had lived.

In the room next door, Mrs. Alvarez clutched a faded photograph, her fingers tracing the outlines of her children. “It’s just hospice,” she would say, her voice barely above a whisper, as if speaking it aloud might make it more real. Her daughter, Ana, sat by her side, her hands restless in her lap. “Is there anything more we can do?” she asked Emily, desperation threading her words. Emily’s reply was steady, practiced: “We’re doing everything we can.”

The routine was comforting in its predictability, yet beneath it simmered a tension, a knowing that each day could bring the unexpected. The hospice was a place of waiting, of moments suspended between hope and acceptance. Emily had learned to navigate this liminal space, her heart attuned to the unspoken needs of her patients.

As she moved through the building, Emily paused at room seven. Inside, a young woman named Clara lay amidst a sea of white sheets, her breath a fragile thing. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thompson, hovered nearby, their faces etched with exhaustion and love. “It’s just hospice,” Mr. Thompson muttered, his voice thick with finality. Emily offered him a smile, small but sincere, a lighthouse in the fog of their grief.

“How are you feeling today, Clara?” Emily asked, her voice a gentle coaxing. Clara’s eyes flickered open, a faint smile ghosting across her lips. “I’m ready,” she said, the words a surprise, even to herself. In that moment, the air shifted, the heaviness lifting ever so slightly, like a curtain drawn back to reveal a sliver of light.

The words echoed through the hospice, a ripple of change that touched each room. Gerald, upon hearing the news, sat a little straighter in his bed. “Ready,” he repeated to himself, the syllables rolling off his tongue like a prayer. Mrs. Alvarez, too, seemed to find solace in the words, her grip on the photograph relaxing as she exhaled a long-held breath. Ana watched her mother, a flicker of understanding passing between them.

Emily continued her rounds, the mantra of “How are you feeling today?” now carrying a newfound resonance. She lingered in each room, her presence a balm. The word “hospice” began to shift, its meaning evolving from a place of finality to one of quiet acceptance. It was still a space where life waned, but now it was also a place where life was honored, each moment cherished.

In the days that followed, Clara’s words continued to echo, their impact profound. The patients and their families began to see the hospice not as an end, but as a space where love lingered, where memories were woven into the fabric of the walls. The staff noticed the change, too, their interactions with patients and families carrying a gentle warmth, a shared understanding of what it meant to be truly present.

One afternoon, as the sun dipped low on the horizon, casting long shadows through the hospice windows, Emily found herself sitting with Gerald. They talked of small things: the weather, the birds outside his window, the stories of his youth. “I’ve been thinking,” Gerald said, his voice thoughtful. “Maybe I’m ready, too.” His words were not of resignation, but of peace, a quiet acceptance of what was to come.

In another room, Mrs. Alvarez and Ana sat in silence, their hands entwined. “It’s a place of peace,” Ana whispered, her voice a tender caress. Her mother nodded, a soft smile playing on her lips. The photograph lay beside them, a testament to a life well-lived, to love enduring beyond the confines of time.

As Emily prepared to leave for the day, she paused in the hallway, her heart full. The hospice, with its quiet corridors and rooms filled with stories, had transformed. It was a place where hope had not vanished, but had simply taken on a new form, a gentler light that illuminated the path for those who found themselves within its walls.

The next morning, as Emily began her rounds, the familiar question fell from her lips with ease. “How are you feeling today?” she asked, and the responses came, each one a testament to the journey they were all on together. “I’m ready,” they said, or “I’m at peace,” or simply “I’m here.”

In the end, it was not about the destination, but the journey, the moments of connection that defined their days. The hospice was still a place of waiting, but now it was also a sanctuary, a haven where love and light intertwined, creating a tapestry of hope and acceptance.

Emily moved from room to room, her heart a quiet drumbeat in the symphony of life that surrounded her. The word “hospice” had become something more, a place not of endings, but of beginnings, each day a new chapter in the story of those who found themselves within its embrace.

When the word "hospice" is first spoken, it feels like the air itself changes, heavy with finality. Clara hears it and feels an almost imperceptible shift in the universe, a closing door. It’s her mother, Marjorie, who the doctor is addressing, but the word reverberates through Clara’s own heart, a dull thud of inevitability.

Marjorie stares at the doctor with a mix of resignation and defiance, her once-vibrant green eyes now clouded by the long battle with illness. She nods slowly, her lips pressed into a thin line, and then looks away, out the window where a soft autumn rain begins to fall. Clara watches her mother’s profile, the sharp lines softened by the afternoon light, and feels a pang of something she cannot name.

They return home, the word "hospice" now a silent companion that follows them through the days. Clara finds herself moving through the motions of care with an urgency that surprises her. She arranges visits from the nurses, fills out forms, and talks in hushed tones with her mother’s friends, who come bearing casseroles and quiet condolences.

In the evenings, after the house has settled into its own kind of weary quiet, Clara sits by her mother’s bedside, reading aloud from old favorites—books they had shared during long summer afternoons when she was a child. Marjorie listens with her eyes closed, a faint smile playing at the corners of her mouth, her breath shallow but steady. It is in these moments that Clara feels the weight of loss most acutely, the slow erosion of time slipping through their fingers.

One evening, as the fire in the hearth crackles and the shadows lengthen, Marjorie opens her eyes and reaches for Clara’s hand. Her touch is light, almost ethereal, and Clara feels a sudden rush of tears she struggles to hold back.

“Clara,” Marjorie says softly, her voice barely a whisper. “Do you remember the garden?”

Clara nods, unable to speak. The garden had been Marjorie’s sanctuary, a riot of color and life where she had spent countless hours tending to roses, tulips, and wildflowers. It had been Clara’s playground, a place of wonder and discovery, where she had learned the names of plants and the rhythms of nature.

“I want to see it,” Marjorie says, her eyes shining with a faint glimmer of the old spark. “One last time.”

Clara hesitates, the practical part of her mind already listing the reasons why it might be impossible. But then she sees the determination in her mother’s gaze, the unspoken plea, and she nods.

The next morning, Clara arranges for a wheelchair and blankets, wrapping Marjorie in layers to keep the chill at bay. She pushes her mother through the narrow hallway and out into the garden, where the late autumn sun bathes the world in a golden glow. The air is crisp, filled with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves, and Clara feels a strange sense of peace settle over her.

Marjorie breathes in deeply, her eyes scanning the familiar landscape. The garden is past its prime, the flowers wilted and the branches bare, but there is a beauty in the decay, a quiet dignity in the way the world prepares for winter.

Clara wheels her mother to the old wooden bench under the maple tree, its leaves a brilliant tapestry of reds and golds. She sits beside her, their hands still entwined, and they watch the world together, the silence between them filled with unspoken memories.

For a while, they sit in companionable silence, the only sounds the rustling of leaves and the distant chirping of birds. Clara feels a warmth spread through her, a sense of connection that transcends words. It is as if the garden itself is holding them, cradling them in its embrace, offering a kind of solace that she hadn’t realized she needed.

Marjorie turns to her, her eyes filled with a mixture of gratitude and sadness. “Thank you, Clara,” she says, her voice trembling. “For everything.”

“Hospice.” The doctor’s voice was soft, yet the word cut through the room like a chisel. Everyone stopped, the air itself seemed to halt, heavy with an unspoken understanding. The family sat in a semicircle, their expressions shifting from disbelief to acceptance, and then, slowly, settling into a quiet resolve. Mary, who had been dabbing her eyes with a tissue, felt the weight of the word settle in her chest, anchoring her to her chair.

The room, a small, sunlit corner of the hospital, suddenly felt suffocating. Outside, the world continued with its oblivious bustle, but inside, time seemed to pause. It was Mary’s father, Harold, who broke the silence first. His voice was unexpectedly steady. “Well,” he said, “I suppose that’s that, then.” But his eyes, usually so sharp and mischievous, were now clouded with a mixture of fear and acceptance.

The doctor, a kind-faced woman with gentle hands and a calm demeanor, nodded. “There’s still time, Mr. Thompson. Time for moments that matter. Hospice isn’t the end; it’s about the quality of life.”

Mary wanted to believe her. She looked around the room, at her brothers who sat stoically, and her mother, who seemed to shrink into herself. The air was thick, but as the doctor spoke, Mary noticed a thin beam of sunlight filtering through the window, dust particles dancing in its glow. It was a gentle reminder that light could pierce even the heaviest of shadows.

In the days that followed, Mary found herself returning to that image, the sunlight breaking through. The hospice center, where her father was moved, was a place of serene acceptance. The corridors were quiet, filled with the soft hum of medical equipment, and the gentle rustle of curtains as they swayed with each passing breeze. There was a garden outside, vibrant with autumn colors, where Mary often found solace.

Her father, despite the circumstances, retained his dry humor. “Looks like I’ve got a one-way ticket,” he joked one afternoon, winking at Mary. She chuckled, albeit with tears in her eyes. “Don’t you dare make that your stand-up routine,” she replied, her voice catching in her throat.

The nurses were a balm to her frayed nerves. One in particular, Nurse Jill, seemed to have a knack for lightening the atmosphere. She would come in with a story or a joke, her laughter bright and contagious. “Why did the scarecrow win an award?” she asked one day, as she adjusted Harold’s pillows. “Because he was outstanding in his field!” Even Harold, who had heard it before, couldn’t help but smile.

Mary marveled at how these small acts of kindness, these moments of levity, could lift the weight that had settled over them. The hospice was not just a place of endings, but also of unexpected beginnings—connections and reflections that might never have happened otherwise.

One afternoon, as Mary sat by her father’s bedside, he turned to her, his eyes clear and focused. “Do you remember the summer we built that treehouse?” he asked suddenly. Mary nodded, a smile tugging at her lips. “You insisted on painting it bright blue,” she recalled. “Said it would match the sky.”

Harold chuckled, a soft, rasping sound. “It was the most crooked thing I ever built, but you loved it anyway.” They sat in silence for a moment, the memory wrapping around them like a warm blanket. Outside, the garden shimmered in the late afternoon sun, the colors vivid and alive.

As the days passed, Mary found herself drawn to the garden more often. It was here that she encountered a scene that seemed almost magical. A patient, an elderly woman with silver hair, sat in her wheelchair, eyes closed, a serene smile on her lips. Around her, in her mind’s eye, the garden transformed into a vibrant tapestry of colors and sounds. She imagined it alive with laughter and the voices of loved ones long gone.

Mary watched, entranced, as the woman’s face lit up with an inner joy, untouched by the shadows of her surroundings. It was a moment that seemed to transcend reality, a reminder that even in the face of finality, there could be beauty and light.

Inspired, Mary began to bring small tokens of brightness into her father’s room. She placed fresh flowers on the windowsill, their colors bright against the stark white of the walls. She brought books filled with his favorite stories, reading to him in the quiet hours of the afternoon. And always, there was music—soft, soothing melodies that filled the room with warmth.

Her father, too, found solace in these simple pleasures. He would listen intently as Mary read, his eyes closed, a faint smile on his lips. “I never thought I’d find peace here,” he admitted one evening, “but somehow, I do.” His words were a balm to Mary’s aching heart, a testament to the power of light in the darkest of times.

As the days turned to weeks, the weight of the initial word—hospice—began to lift, replaced by a gentle acceptance. Mary learned to cherish the moments, the laughter, and even the tears, for they were a testament to the life her father had lived.

On a crisp autumn morning, as the leaves danced in the breeze outside the window, Harold took his last breath. The room was filled with a profound stillness, yet there was also a sense of peace. Mary sat beside him, holding his hand, feeling the warmth of the sun on her face. She knew, in that moment, that the light had not vanished but had simply transformed, leaving behind a glow that would guide her in the days to come.

In the quiet aftermath, as Mary stepped into the garden, she understood that hope was not a fleeting thing. It was a constant, like the sunlight that broke through the clouds, a gentle reminder that even in the shadow of loss, life continued in all its beauty and complexity.

story_b:
In the hospice, days unfolded like pages in a tattered book, worn at the edges from the repeated turning of chapters that promised little change. The air, thick with antiseptic and whispered regrets, shifted subtly the first time the word "hospice" was spoken, as if the walls themselves absorbed its weight, bowing slightly inward, holding secrets of both despair and quiet resolve.

Another day, another round. Nurse Evelyn moved through the corridors with the practiced grace of one who had long since learned to navigate the tightrope of empathy and detachment. The hospice was a place of transitions, and she had witnessed many—a last breath, a reconciliatory embrace, a tearful goodbye. Each room held its own story, and Evelyn was part keeper, part witness.

"How are we feeling today?" she asked in a soft, rhythmic cadence as she entered Room 4, where Mr. Harper lay, his form barely disturbing the white expanse of the bed. His eyes, clouded with resignation yet flickering with a stubborn spark of hope, met hers. They had their routine, Mr. Harper and Evelyn. Each morning, she would ask, and each morning he would respond with the same wry smile, "Still here."

Mr. Harper's son, David, visited every Sunday, his presence a reluctant duty wrapped in love and regret. He sat by the window, staring out at the garden that stretched beyond the glass, vibrant even in winter, as if mocking the sterility within. Evelyn had seen him there many times, his profile etched with a quiet determination, struggling to find words that wouldn’t come.

The misunderstanding began with a silence—Mr. Harper's silence. It was the previous Sunday when David, in a moment of frustration, had pleaded, "Dad, do you want me to make arrangements? Is this what you want?" And in the heavy quiet that followed, he had taken the silence as consent, as acceptance.

But Evelyn knew better. That evening, as she tidied the room, she found the letter—hidden beneath a stack of well-worn books, its envelope yellowed with age. Inside, Mr. Harper had scrawled his desires, his fears, and his love in a shaky hand. "I want to see the ocean again," it read. "I want to feel the sand, hear the waves. I want to remember how it was to live."

The discovery of the letter became a turning point—a moment when the routine shattered, revealing raw, unspoken truths. Evelyn held the letter in her hand, its weight surprisingly light yet burdened with Mr. Harper's unfulfilled dreams. She knew she had to act, to bring light into a place where hope seemed to have vanished.

The next Sunday, David arrived, his expression a mask of weary expectation. Evelyn approached him gently, the letter carefully tucked into her pocket. "David," she began, "there's something you should see." She led him to a quiet room where they could talk undisturbed.

As David unfolded the letter, his face transformed, the mask slipping away to reveal a mixture of shock and sorrow. "I didn’t know," he whispered, his voice cracking. "I thought he had given up."

Evelyn placed a reassuring hand on his shoulder. "He hasn't," she said softly. "There's still time."

Together, they devised a plan—a final journey, a chance to fulfill Mr. Harper's wish. It was risky, perhaps even foolish, but David was resolute. Hope, once a distant memory, began to take shape, fragile yet persistent.

On a chilly morning, under a sky that promised rain, Evelyn and David wheeled Mr. Harper through the hospice doors, his frail body bundled in blankets. He watched the world unfold around him with a childlike wonder, his eyes wide with anticipation. The drive to the coast was long, the hours passing in a blur of conversation and silence, punctuated by the hum of the engine and the rhythmic beat of the windshield wipers.

When they arrived, the sea stretched before them, vast and endless, its waves crashing against the shore with a ferocity that seemed to echo Mr. Harper's own struggle. David lifted his father from the wheelchair, supporting him as they made their way to the water's edge. Mr. Harper's feet sank into the sand, the grains cool and familiar.

Evelyn watched from a distance, her heart swelling with an unfamiliar warmth. It was a rare moment of triumph, a reminder that even in places shrouded in darkness, light could be found.

Mr. Harper stood at the edge of the world, the ocean before him a testament to life’s enduring beauty. The wind whipped through his hair, and he laughed—a sound so full of joy that it startled even him. He turned to David, his eyes brimming with gratitude.
